review: 3.5 stars. This is a time compressed family drama where you are drawn into a tight family circle and then, with great dismay, watch it shatter. Each s3.5 stars. This is a time compressed family drama where you are drawn into a tight family circle and then, with great dismay, watch it shatter. Each sister has the strength to make choices that will help them to live the life they choose but the repercussions for themselves and the rest of the family ultimately become unbearable - they are family and need each other. It was also difficult to watch William’s actions as it seemed almost destined to create the same childhood trauma that he experienced. The ripple effect of individual decisions, outward and downward (generationally) has a devastating effect on every family member, and these events propel you through this novel.I liked the multiple viewpoints around which this novel was structured. At different points in time each character had their challenges and successes and it allowed you to feel intimately involved....more

review: I thought this was quite a beautiful and reflective novel about how we all imagine our lives to be entirely unique and how we imagine our futures. It I thought this was quite a beautiful and reflective novel about how we all imagine our lives to be entirely unique and how we imagine our futures. It is only on reflection that it might be possible to see that we ignored signs and mistook relationships. This day begins at the point of no return and ends with the aftermath of tragedy. It is felt significantly, but differently, by each character. I was also intrigued by the use of a fictional Instagram persona created by Robbie and sustained by Isabel. This is how an imaginary character can be created with a perfect life and exist for eternity. Followers seem to ‘choose’ to believe in a perfect existence despite obvious flaws in the posts of ‘Wolfe’....more

review: 3.5 stars. This is a rather quiet unassuming story about that period of your life when you have left middle age but are not yet ‘elderly’. Things are 3.5 stars. This is a rather quiet unassuming story about that period of your life when you have left middle age but are not yet ‘elderly’. Things are changing, you’re slowing down, forgetting occasionally, reflecting on life choices - retirement and what you still want to achieve. I can imagine that while this doesn’t happen suddenly the realisation that you have entered this zone might appear quite sudden and brutal. Baumgartner is in his early 70’s and has realised that he will probably never have another long term relationship and that while he grieved for his wife (who died unexpectedly early) he has not seized the opportunity to honour her memory. This realisation spurs him to make changes in his life and reflect on the depth of this relationship from its inception. A slow paced, quiet story but a lovely one....more

review: I’m still thinking about why I enjoyed this book. It is not a book that I can easily quantify. On the one hand the story becomes quite bogged down in I’m still thinking about why I enjoyed this book. It is not a book that I can easily quantify. On the one hand the story becomes quite bogged down in detail, it frequently rehashes events and we spend a lot of time in the internal monologue of Aose, the protagonist. However, I also liked that it wasn’t trying to showcase literary ‘tricks’ or red herrings, it was a straightforward narrative that just required patience. I also thought the explanations of architecture as art were thoughtful and actually made me think about how design can really impact your vision or state of mind. This was definitely a palate cleanser and stylistically quite different from a lot of contemporary literary fiction....more

review: 3.5 stars. This is a thought provoking debut and Yu has really delved into what it means to be a second generation immigrant, to belong and not to bel3.5 stars. This is a thought provoking debut and Yu has really delved into what it means to be a second generation immigrant, to belong and not to belong to a country you have been born and raised in. Her character is also trying to understand how she fits into a literary world that is predominantly white and how we can view writers that came before us without cancelling everything that doesn’t fit our contemporary sensibility. While these are serious subjects there is also humour in how she exposes and explores her attempts to understand herself and the actions of others.I lived in Malaysia for a couple of years in my early 30’s and I have a deep affection for it. I had several flashbacks to my time there and the interactions that I had. I’m looking forward to reading Jessica Yu’s next book....more

title: Tremor
author: Cole, Teju
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: While this is a novel it often felt like nonfiction because it is so heavily blended with facts about art, history, music, literature and cinema. ColeWhile this is a novel it often felt like nonfiction because it is so heavily blended with facts about art, history, music, literature and cinema. Cole is making a point that many of the ‘things’ we revere in our museums, galleries and theatres represent the cost of colonialism, war and theft. Reminders are everywhere and while there is some acknowledgment and reparations much more needs to be done.There were some powerful quotes in this book and a long list of paintings, movies, literature and music to check out. I needed (Wanted) to keep a list. I have not been to any of the galleries referred to and was unfamiliar with much of what was mentioned. About two thirds of the way through there is a chapter of polyphonic voiced vignettes of people who live, or have lived, part of their lives in Lagos. At first I was confused about what was going to happen but began to feel I had arrived in a busy unknown city, wondering what everyone was doing and how they lived. There are also switches between first and second person that cleverly draw the reader into the story.This is definitely not a book for anyone that is looking for a straightforward plot driven story. It is extremely thought provoking and meditative, the writing is considered and beautiful.“He wants to take in what is useful from the world not in order to plunder it but in order to live.”“But when a man’s existential satisfaction depends on not knowing something he very much will find a way to not know it.”...more

review: While this is,literally, a book set at some time in the future in Dublin it could also be the past or the present and it could be set in any number ofWhile this is,literally, a book set at some time in the future in Dublin it could also be the past or the present and it could be set in any number of places and it could be non-fiction. This is what makes this book so impactful. As a parent, child, sibling or, just a member of society this felt visceral and important. In an era where we are constantly bombarded with news stories of people in traumatic circumstances it becomes numbing and to imagine how we would personally deal with having family go missing, our life and occupation threatened or deficient of basic resources is not easy subject matter. This book presents this scenario and it is harrowing. This is not an enjoyable read but it is powerful and I will be thinking about it for some time....more

title: Question 7
author: Flanagan, Richard
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: We can’t know anyone apart from what they want to share and in this offering- autobiography, memoir, biography (real and imagined) Flanagan shares hisWe can’t know anyone apart from what they want to share and in this offering- autobiography, memoir, biography (real and imagined) Flanagan shares his story, and that of the lives that he believes have intersected it. Like rays of light he bounces off things in dark spaces, illuminating moments, events and people. Sometimes the light only creates shadows so he describes what is in that darkness, or imagines it through the use of historical text (relying on other narrators). Using the indigenous idea of a fourth time dimension (he acknowledges this in his text) he pulls and tugs on the past, present and future and creates a story that weaves in and out of his life. This must have taken a great deal of courage to write, it simultaneously acknowledges the smallness and greatness of each human life. How lucky we are and how we should find moments to be grateful. It is a beautiful tribute to his parents and his island home of Tasmania....more

review: 4.5 stars. Yes I did love this book but must also disclose a bias because my name has been used as a character, and yes it’s a good one. Thanks Lucy T4.5 stars. Yes I did love this book but must also disclose a bias because my name has been used as a character, and yes it’s a good one. Thanks Lucy Treloar! A steady building of tension and enough disorientation to keep you wondering if this is a reliable narrator. What has she really remembered from the kidnapping of her best friend? It is hard to imagine the long term trauma of witnessing an event like that and Treloar has skilfully woven this story. The outback noir is vividly depicted and firmly rooted in this quintessential Australian town, that is on the brink of non existence. It is the people and their shared history that bind this crumbling town and create a memorable story....more

review: 4.5 stars . I love how Charlotte Wood was able to convincingly insinuate herself into this setting through her protagonist. I was fully convinced by h4.5 stars . I love how Charlotte Wood was able to convincingly insinuate herself into this setting through her protagonist. I was fully convinced by her portrayal of a woman who is seeking (or hiding) from understanding of how we can make sense or atone for the many missteps we all make in life. As she reminisces about her own miscalculations in life she also perceives her own mother’s life through the mirage that is childhood, making her mother appear saintly and courageous. We are vaguely made aware that the cloistered women in this story have retreated (or found cause) because they have found themselves lacking in someway or they prefer to not deal with life beyond an essential existence.The mouse plague creates the perfect atmosphere of dread and collapse in our environment, that is unfortunately a real phenomenon. The story of Helen Parry (and what a great name) made me wonder how some people are able to find a way to push through the negative experiences in life and choose to make themselves bigger while other people shrink into a smaller world....more

review: The travel journal part of this book was predominantly why I read this book. After recently visiting Morocco I was interested to understand how it mayThe travel journal part of this book was predominantly why I read this book. After recently visiting Morocco I was interested to understand how it may have appeared to early 20 th century (western) travellers. Wharton was successful in transmitting this image and I was able to recognise many of the vistas she described. Her descriptions of landscape and daily life were fascinating. The second half of the book, which promotes the French administration, was less interesting to me (and it is likely biased and opinionated in a way that is probably considered dated now). I guess that is history and it just needs to be appreciated as a part of the story. ...more

review: This was an intriguing read exploring how grief and regret collide. A major theme of this novel was its visceral descriptions of how bodily functions This was an intriguing read exploring how grief and regret collide. A major theme of this novel was its visceral descriptions of how bodily functions continue and are autonomous to the emotions that Remei (the narrator) experiences after the death of her husband. She is unable to switch off or control her body despite the overwhelming grief she suffers. This seems to descend her into madness as she desperately fights to punish herself and shut down her body. Her survivor guilt is harrowing. I also liked the way there were elements of fictional ‘local legend’ woven into the story. review: Don’t let the name or cover deceive you. This is not a gentle or cosy read. It is powerful, confronting and provocative. It will probe you to assess yDon’t let the name or cover deceive you. This is not a gentle or cosy read. It is powerful, confronting and provocative. It will probe you to assess your biases and opinions on race, religion and what it means to be Australian. This is the novel that Maya (the matriarch of this story) could not write or sell for her predominantly while Australian audience.There are some beautiful and humorous scenes but the novel does predominantly explore some unflinching grim realities. While, as an Australian, it might be easy to condemn the treatment of Tamils in Sri Lanka it is not easy to dismiss the criticism of the treatment of immigrants (non-European) in Australia as inaccurate or exaggerated. Sadly there is probably a lot of truth and reality behind the events of this book, despite being fictional. In parts this is a deeply distressing novel and shows how quickly events can turn from casual racism to hate.As a major prize winning novel in Australia I think there is acknowledgment that the the time has come for the diaspora of Australian citizens to look in on itself and reflect on how we can move forward as a more just and inclusive society. Accepting our past wrongs is a big part of this process too....more

review: 4.5 stars. A monumental, detailed and vivid (imagined) description of life during the final two years of WW11. Set predominately in the Italian alps, 4.5 stars. A monumental, detailed and vivid (imagined) description of life during the final two years of WW11. Set predominately in the Italian alps, where the partisans and local residents shielded fleeing Jews, this story swirls between perspectives. Unlikely heroes emerge as the situation deteriorates and conditions become desperate. This is visceral and tense. While there are moments of joy it it overwhelmingly about choosing from unbearable options. This is quite a long book, 500 odd pages, and for me it was a slow read as there were a large number of locations, logistics and characters to piece together. It was probably my slowest read of the year but definitely worth it. The descriptions of place and events are carefully crafted and depicted. There was clearly a lot of research, and Russell writes about the process in short note at the end of the novel. ...more

title: Wandering with Intent
author: Mahood, Kim
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Kim take you on a fascinating wander through the spectacular Australian outback where she has spent much of her life. This series of essays explores hKim take you on a fascinating wander through the spectacular Australian outback where she has spent much of her life. This series of essays explores how her experience of the land, the people who inhabit it and those who attempt to provide services, management and governance within it have shaped it. We glimpse into her thinking on why white an black people have struggled to shape a relationship that can effectively balance managing themselves and this delicate ecosystem. As Kim says this balance is fraught with problems of guilt, misunderstanding, miscommunication, family obligation and isolation. “It’s here that I have been inducted into the rigours of two-way thinking, and taught how to let contradictions play through each other instead of trying to resolve them. …. I have learnt that too rigorous an attachment to outcomes disenfranchises the Aboriginal participants, and that the most important discoveries are often the things you aren’t looking for. I have learnt that serendipity is essential to success of a project, and that knowing how to leave space for serendipity is a skill that can only be learned through long experience.” Her primary employment (interest?) is in “imaginative mapping “ of indigenous lands. Working with local Aboriginal people she collates and maps information on plant and animal resources, bush medicine, country types, water resources and any cultural information that the local people wish to include. She maps local language and knowledge in a way that is helping to preserve connection and maintain knowledge.These essays are a glimpse into a life lived walking a delicate balance observing and participating in a place and culture that continues to be poorly understood but much discussed and judged. Kim’s gentle humour and insight gave me much to think about....more

title: The Anniversary
author: Bishop, Stephanie
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I particularly liked the structure of this book, the way the major plot events unfolded. A story is always about the particular events that a narratorI particularly liked the structure of this book, the way the major plot events unfolded. A story is always about the particular events that a narrator or protagonist reveals and this is what we then use to base our emotions and understanding. As an author, like our narrator (Lucie) or a film producer/director (like her deceased husband Patrick) they choose to only reveal particular details about themselves. In the first half of this story we begin with the terrible accident and then Lucie flashes us back and forth in time sharing her current trauma, her childhood and the love story that she shared with her husband. There is a discomforting buildup of concern during the first half, the reader knows there is another version of this story. The second half of the book reveals this and dread and confusion lurk in each unfolding moment. Patrick and Lucie are interesting and complex- not fully good or bad - problematic. Occasionally our narrator (author) got a bit long winded in explaining something- I think this could have happened less. I was also not sure that all the events revealed in the story were necessary or added to the plot. While the trip to Australia could have been crucial for revealing the narrator’s past, reconnecting with her family or providing future support it felt quite isolated from the rest of the story. The narrator was a really insular character so I didn’t feel like any other character contributed a lot to her story.My first book by Bishop but certainly an author I’ll be looking forward to reading more from....more

review: I thoroughly enjoyed this collection of stories that explore the theme of metamorphosis of human lives. Death, marriage, adultery, relationships and tI thoroughly enjoyed this collection of stories that explore the theme of metamorphosis of human lives. Death, marriage, adultery, relationships and travel are explored as moments in time when a life can take a sudden turn and be upended. Lively uses sharp wit and mischievous humour to explore these complex moments, relationships and the discrepancy between inner dialogue (what we think) and what is voiced out loud (what we say). This is a wonderfully narrated audio because it makes the most of these nuances.This is the second  I’ve written- my first crashed/deleted before I hit the Done button (it was better) frustrating because who likes to re-write....more

I was fascinated by the way this weaved the story of Neffy’s relationship with an octopus - using journal entries and ‘revisits’ into past memories. The octopuses human ‘like’ qualities were cleverly worked into this story and worked well to exam the idea of what it means to capture and cage a sentient being. Under what circumstances can a person experience similar trauma ? I also liked the exploration of the lengths that people will go to for others but simultaneously how selfish they can be. review: I’m sorry I’ve never heard of Janet Malcolm or previously read her writing but I’m pleased that I stumbled (I read/heard a recommendation) across thisI’m sorry I’ve never heard of Janet Malcolm or previously read her writing but I’m pleased that I stumbled (I read/heard a recommendation) across this book. While it is autobiographical it does not require any prior knowledge or really any particular interest in the writer. It captures a life, that like many, (including my own) comes from a very middle class, ordinary background and yet somehow she turns this into a fleshed out book via a collection of images. I like how she doesn’t remember every detail of the photo and sometimes she can’t recall the people but yet she does retain a sense of the time and place around these moments. It is also done with a humorous touch that makes you feel included in the joke but never seeks to blame or humiliate anyone. It’s just a lived life. ...more

review: 3.5 stars. I listened to this as an audio. This was a fascinating debut novel and while I initially thought it was only going to be a fictional versio3.5 stars. I listened to this as an audio. This was a fascinating debut novel and while I initially thought it was only going to be a fictional version of a similar legal situation that is currently in the Australian court system I was pleased that it explored much more.Being born into an ultra orthodox community must be extremely challenging. This is about what you must accept or give-up if you want to belong or leave these communities. When choice is removed the characters in this novel, Ezra and Yonatan, are crushed by their inability to navigate between personal ideologies and those of their religious faith. They are both on different journeys attempting to establish their identities however their stories are linked through childhood friendship. There are many shades of grey in this novel and it provides a carefully portrayed glimpse into a world, that for me, was quite confounding and sometimes inexplicable in its rigidity to maintain law rather than to the protect the vulnerable....more

Inexplicably man is never happy … he destroys what he creates and does not value anything that is not power. This epic tale considers the follies of many civilisations and what ultimately undoes them - viewed through the eyes of an enchantress. The narrator, who is interpreting the words written by the enchantress, has a wry sense of humour as each generation ultimately meets its demise. review: 3.5 stars. This story presents a thoughtful glimpse at the lives of mixed racial children, victims of the Vietnam War and its aftermath. I believe thi3.5 stars. This story presents a thoughtful glimpse at the lives of mixed racial children, victims of the Vietnam War and its aftermath. I believe this book blends a number of situations based on some real life stories the author has encountered. The stories are complex in that while many of these children were loved by at least one parent they were often abandoned. The attempts to reunite these children with their families has become more accessible over the years with increasing technology like DNA testing. While this provides hope for some it also presents many difficulties including complex trauma, unobtainable expectations and grief.Perhaps writing this as a novel has meant that some of these experiences have had to be simplified (and there are very unlikely coincidences) in order to create a narrative arc but overall it is a successful and enlightening story....more

title: The Furrows
author: Serpell, Namwali*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A brilliant read. One of those books where you keep thinking you can see where it’s going and what’s happening but it’s like you’re walking through foA brilliant read. One of those books where you keep thinking you can see where it’s going and what’s happening but it’s like you’re walking through fog getting glimpses of something that are surely trees but turn out to be shadows. There are also evocative descriptions and imagery that create a powerful sense of place and tip into the realm of speculative fiction. Sometimes not knowing exactly what is happening in a plot can be annoying but Serpell uses this as a powerful narrative crafting tool to hone in on the premise of the story - a child is presumed dead but the body is missing. Serpell has thrown the reader into the same situation as the characters— what is really happening? , is memory reliable? , how do you move on when you have no closure? The change in narrator, later in the story, throws the reader again. The voice of Wayne is texturally so different and his story is compelling. At this stage I was just hoping to not have some fantastical Hollywood ending to the story. Thankfully it does not.Imagining how people live on with missing family is such a compelling premise and this novel explores many of the possible traumatic implications. Recently the father of the missing Beaumont children (this is a very famous Australian case - google it) passed away. I can’t imagine the burden of how not knowing impacted his entire life....more

review: This was a smart and contemporary reflection on how we look back and make understandings on past lives based on our own lives. The narrator, Alice, fiThis was a smart and contemporary reflection on how we look back and make understandings on past lives based on our own lives. The narrator, Alice, finds many similarities between her life and that of Leonard and Virginia Woolf. Ultimately we are not that different (our trajectory- like a meteor remains similar) and chance events and pure luck see us live out our lives with the gradual dwindling of family and friends. The use of ‘ghost’ Leonard and Virginia allowed Cunningham to share so many extra bits of information that may otherwise have felt forced or overburdened the story. In a bit of humour she often reflects that these snippets may not really be necessary to the plot.Ultimately I loved that Cunningham didn’t make this feel like a definitive story about the Woolf’s. She acknowledges the vast opinions and tries to share the complexity that is unearthed- the more you know the less you realise you do know....more

review: Utterly devastating and brilliant. This is an amazing novel because despite the horrific violence there is also the most beautiful compassion. When viUtterly devastating and brilliant. This is an amazing novel because despite the horrific violence there is also the most beautiful compassion. When violence is fuelled by drugs and poverty and perpetrated by those that you should be able to trust (the most) it is hard to imagine where you would turn to get help.The characters in this novel are complex and the structure simultaneously builds a background and present day which connects at a point when you can grasp the complexity of the situation. The embedded traditions and language of the indigenous NZ are also included in a way that added so much significance to this story and did not feel gratuitous or unnecessary. author: Drndić, Daša

review: I had moments where I was totally engrossed and parts where I felt the story was meandering and I lost my way. Obviously there is a huge amount to be I had moments where I was totally engrossed and parts where I felt the story was meandering and I lost my way. Obviously there is a huge amount to be said about the holocaust and this made it difficult to narrow down the content. I was also concerned that labelling this as fiction meant I was never sure exactly what I could rely on as fact. I googled quite a number of events but even that became overwhelming. In the end I just read and settled that this was an exploration of many victims, perpetrators and bystanders. I can’t imagine how difficult it must be to accept you are descended from someone that committed heinous atrocities to other people and how even today so many people don’t know their own origin story. There is also a lot of (justified) anger in this story. The last few chapters were particularly powerful and pushed me to give this 4 stars....more

title: Bila Yarrudhanggalangdhuray
author: Heiss, Anita*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: 3.5 stars. A story that focuses on the forced occupation of indigenous land and its consequences for Aboriginal people (in particular) around Gundagai3.5 stars. A story that focuses on the forced occupation of indigenous land and its consequences for Aboriginal people (in particular) around Gundagai and Wagga Wagga in New South Wales. The story begins with the flood of Gundagai and the heroic actions of the indigenous men who risked their lives to rescue white settlers -this is based on true events - and was the part I was most interested in. The lack of recognition and appreciation is astonishing but not surprising given how the indigenous people were treated at this time.The themes of connection with land and family in this novel only focuses on a few characters and I felt many remained unchanged by the events of this novel and showed no evolution through the story - both by the settlers and the indigenous. While I understand the ‘fixed’ mindset of many settlers, particularly with regards to the treatment of Aboriginal people, this meant there was really no unexpected events or development in the plot. This story is interesting for those that don’t know much about the way white settlement occupied and forced traditional owners from their land and Heiss does a lovely job of including indigenous language in her novel. It is one of many novels (in recent years) that seek to rebalance the historical literary landscape of Australia....more

title: The Pull of the Stars
author: Donoghue, Emma*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: 3.5 stars. A book set at the end of WWI, during the influenza epidemic and in a Northern Ireland hospital- specifically a maternity ward for influenza3.5 stars. A book set at the end of WWI, during the influenza epidemic and in a Northern Ireland hospital- specifically a maternity ward for influenza patients is, as one would expect, a very sad story. This is a 1st person narrative viewed by a nurse working in this ward. At the beginning I did not particularly enjoy the detailed descriptions of equipment, procedures and work/living conditions. It felt like I was just getting a history lesson- and an unpleasant lesson it is. Gradually as I listened to the story (a well narrated audio book) I overcame this and began to think that maybe this slightly clinical detachment might be the only way to survive the horrific loss of life from influenza and childbirth (a compounded disaster).Then throw in the abuse from the church and shell shocked war veterans and remaining at arms length was definitely a benefit. There is still a very real feeling of empathy that the reader develops for the narrator and a number of significant characters so overall I finished with the feeling that while I had been fed a lot of facts I had also absorbed a sense of place and time dosed with some compassion and kindness for those that struggled against church and State in the hope of a better future....more

author: Kingsolver, Barbara
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: 3.5 stars Kingsolver writes an immersive story that (obviously) comes from the heart. It is many, many years since I read David Copperfield so I was n3.5 stars Kingsolver writes an immersive story that (obviously) comes from the heart. It is many, many years since I read David Copperfield so I was not caught up in any sort of comparison which, I felt, made me able to be fully invested in this novel.The depth and breadth of her characters is rich and I think she provides a valuable glimpse into a place that has been derided, neglected and ridiculed. Her story is more empathetic than sympathetic which I think allows the reader to understand how people can end up in tragic circumstances rather than just feeling sorry for them.As a coming of age novel I felt I was comparing this more with Shuggie Bain (than David Copperfield) and for this reason I gave it 3 stars rather than 4. I think Shuggie Bain added touches of humour that made that story slightly easier to engage with, especially when you know that there is going to be so much darkness. It is also overly long and does feel a bit repetitive in terms of themes and end events.As for the creators and distributors of addictive prescription medications I hope they are eventually called to account. Fortunately the story of these drugs is well known now however it seems unlikely that new victims will not be sourced as these companies certainly know how to target their medications and find vulnerable people....more

review: A gut wrenching book that does not shy from the explicit violence and horror of civil war. This is definitely what is referred to as ‘genre bending’ -A gut wrenching book that does not shy from the explicit violence and horror of civil war. This is definitely what is referred to as ‘genre bending’ - part political spy thriller, ghost story, magical realism, love story and war story. I think I could read this a few times and uncover a lot more … it is very dense and at times hypnotic (I listened to the audio which was wonderfully narrated). Incredibly it is narrated in the second person, which seems like a very difficult choice for such a long book. The main character is also extremely flawed but yet you want him to succeed in finding his killer, I was completely invested in finding a satisfying ending. The presence of many god like creatures made this book feel rooted in its Sri Lankan landscape and a unique examination of the horrific civil was that tore through this country and spared no racial group. I can see why this book won the Booker Prize. It is an excellent piece of writing....more

title: Katalin Street

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is writing that confounds you and breaks your heart but also shows the unique beauty of redemption that the human heart is capable of. After justThis is writing that confounds you and breaks your heart but also shows the unique beauty of redemption that the human heart is capable of. After just finishing Abigail (also by Szabo) I thought it unlikely that I could possibly rate another of her books so highly - but yes I have.This is a raw and exceptionally sensitive book. How can such small, small lives reverberate into such a powerful representation of humanity? This story begins on the cusp of a perfect world but the tiniest crack creates a fissure that swallows the people of Katalin Street and cause irreversible damage. “Once again I was filled with astonishment at just how much the two of them loved Blanka, the one showing it by the harshness of his treatment of her and his total incapacity to forgive, the other so brave and so ready to take action on her behalf.”This book reminds me a lot of the way Elena Ferrante writes characters (although Szabo preceded her - I read Ferrante first). The minutiae of life and the sometimes selfish and passionate mistakes that the characters make are carefully described in a way that makes you feel everything....more

title: Yellow Notebook: Diaries Volume I 1978-1987
author: Garner, Helen
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I think listening to Garner read this is a perfect way to consume her thoughts. Either I was in her head or she was in mine. Sometimes she says thingsI think listening to Garner read this is a perfect way to consume her thoughts. Either I was in her head or she was in mine. Sometimes she says things and I think - I’ve thought that too! But I would never know how to put it on paper in a way that was interesting - that’s her magic. Exploring self doubt, religion and belief, how she handles public criticism, how she observes people - their actions and comments, her grief and sadness about the loss of young life - particularly when violence has been involved, and her struggle to be honest about her meaningful relationships with those closest her, loneliness and ageing (she wasn’t even 40 when she wrote these journal entries). I love the fragmentary sentences - that’s how we think.I love the sneaky wry comments that made me laugh. At one point Garner mentions that she knows she’s not drunk after 3 glasses of Chablis because she has just sewn 2 cushion covers on her old Singer and they fit! “Memo: do not drink coffee. It makes me uselessly nervy even trembly and engenders baseless optimism about my powers of creation” (this is from the audio so excuse my punctuation if it’s not correct)...more

It is definitely a slow searing novel that dealt with issues that were probably extremely difficult to voice at the time when it was written. Domestic violence, alcoholism, patriarchy and religious and social responsibility make for a grim and bleak story. This does not have the accompanying humour of Austen so it does feel quite grinding but the insight into life that Brontë provides is perceptive and quite extraordinary. I definitely needed to listen to this in small segments and for those that are not into excruciating interactions that involve misunderstandings and long winded exchanges that allude to issues rather than speak of them directly I would not recommend this....more

title: Lessons
author: McEwan, Ian*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This novel captures the essence of 21 century life - to simultaneously be no one and somebody. McEwan cleverly lulls us with the familiarity of world This novel captures the essence of 21 century life - to simultaneously be no one and somebody. McEwan cleverly lulls us with the familiarity of world events but then overlays a life that feels discombobulated. If this was a story about a woman it would possibly evoke quite different emotions- grooming a child for sex and desertion of spouse and child are all too familiar themes for women characters. I like how this made me think about how people might respond. Roland certainly suffered enormously and the repercussions were lifelong but what would be the implications of different choices and what (and who) might he have missed.“When he asked himself if he wished none of it had happened he did not have a ready answer. That was the nature of harm.”This quote had me thinking about cancel culture…“The larger subject was the ruthlessness of artists. Do we forgive or ignore their single-mindedness or cruelty in the service of their art? And are we more tolerant the greater the art?”I also felt that a lifetime of writing has allowed McEwan to experience every possible reaction and  to his work and perhaps this was his opportunity to respond. (I know it’s fiction- there’s a lot about that too!)“Also, when a writer has been around long enough people begin to get tired. Even if she does something different every time. They say, she’s doing something different again!”This is a thought provoking novel that asks questions and explores how and why people make choices which are as varied as the individual circumstances of each person’s life. Recommended!...more

author: Snoekstra, Anna*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Thanks to Better Reading and Harper Collins for my copy of Out of Breath. This thriller has an interesting plot with sustained atmosphere and well wriThanks to Better Reading and Harper Collins for my copy of Out of Breath. This thriller has an interesting plot with sustained atmosphere and well written descriptions. The outback regions of Australia have become popular as a setting for crime fiction but this is the first I have read set in the Kimberley region. There have been some real crimes in this area that have evoked strong media coverage and public response so it did have me wondering if I was going to be familiar with the plot but this is definitely original. The ending of the novel was not quite as satisfying as I would have liked. It felt a little overdone and tied up to neatly. Many years ago (about 25) my husband and I got 2 flat tyres on our car when driving between Kununurra and Derby. My husband had to hitch a ride to swap out a spare tire. Meanwhile I was left with our dog and vehicle for a number of hours at the side of the road. It is a very lonely, remote and harsh place and I was quite nervous. I think Snoekstra has vividly captured this....more

review: 4.5 stars. This was wonderful. The question of how and if we truely learn from the past is sadly an ongoing issue. Racism is everywhere and unless we 4.5 stars. This was wonderful. The question of how and if we truely learn from the past is sadly an ongoing issue. Racism is everywhere and unless we continually shine a spotlight on its many forms and acknowledge it (and try to do better) we must accept culpability for the damage and suffering it causes.The two storylines feel effortlessly entwined - which I imagine means they took considerable effort to construct. I wonder if Brooks was feeling nostalgic for Australia and contemplating her own sense of home and place when she wrote this? When I went to see her speak recently she did discuss how she has navigated living over two continents and how family can ultimately connect you and make you choose a particular place.I found the historical detail and the scientific research in this book equally engaging and the art history was an added bonus. This book certainly ticked boxes for content, style, character and execution of the plot....more

review: I found this a book of two halves. The first half was a powerful, emotional imagining of growing up in a tumultuous occupied Africa. Two storylines arI found this a book of two halves. The first half was a powerful, emotional imagining of growing up in a tumultuous occupied Africa. Two storylines are used to trace a young orphaned man called Hamza who voluntarily joins the Germans as a schutztruppe (local soldier). Clearly they were just trained as fodder for war and were treated ruthlessly by their German officers. Hamza quickly realises his error. This was a fascinating (awful and violent) part of the book. The second storyline originally traces another young man, Ilyas, but quickly moves onto a story about his sister, Afiys. Afiya is orphaned and treated badly until her brother locates her and takes her to safety. The second half of the book brings these two storylines together but just didn’t have the same impact. Through years of war and occupation and subsequent and resulting) financial impacts the peoples lives ebb and flow between poverty and some comfort. title: More Than I Love My Life
author: Grossman, David
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I dived into this without any prior knowledge of Goli Otok and was immediately intrigued by what had happened to Vera and the resulting implications fI dived into this without any prior knowledge of Goli Otok and was immediately intrigued by what had happened to Vera and the resulting implications for her family. While I knew there was a big secret I did get a bit displaced in the middle third because I felt excluded from what the characters knew and why they were a splintered family. The esoteric nature of this book nearly made me lose faith that I would understand what was (and had happened ) to Vera. The last 1/3 of the novel was brilliant- Vera’s story and the unimaginable choice she felt compelled to make, followed by her guilt that this secret was so destructive she couldn’t tell Nina. In the end this made me think about how and why we choose not to tell secrets. Sparing pain when it may actually be more painful to know you have been excluded than the actual secret itself.This is probably a confusing a  unless you actually read this book but I can say that it is a very worthwhile read. I also found an interesting clip on tube about Goli Otak https://youtu.be/Zp2Jdsgz9hIand it’s history. It was a prison island for political prisoners of Tito and the regime in Yugoslavia. It was only decommissioned in the 1980’s. Grossman’s novel is inspired by Eva Panic Nahir who “became a symbol of almost superhuman courage, epitomizing the capacity to sustain one’s humanity under the harshest conditions.”...more

title: Build Your House Around My Body
author: Kupersmith, Violet*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Wow, this was a mind bender and I am fascinated with how the author has pulled this together. It is a visceral cacophony and assault on all the sensesWow, this was a mind bender and I am fascinated with how the author has pulled this together. It is a visceral cacophony and assault on all the senses. This novel spans genres, time, settings and POV in an elaborate sinewy way. Like the reoccurring vipers (a note of caution for people with a phobia of snakes) the story twists in and around on itself in ever decreasing circles (there’s a reticulated python analogy for you too!).Kupersmith brings Vietnam into sharp focus. Her descriptions of historical events and locations are recreated through smell, taste and sound in a way that was totally immersive. I could vividly remember visiting some of these places despite it being more than 25 years since I visited Vietnam.Examining generational trauma, coercion, corruption, racism, abuse,colonisation (and nearly every vileness you can imagine) the author seeks to create a story that imagines how a person can reinvent themselves in a new body. It’s a lot to deal with and the magical realism allows the revenge to be palatable in what would otherwise be a depressing and (unfortunately) familiar story.The style of this book reminds me a lot of The Book of Form and Emptiness by Ruth Ozeki - that may give you some indication of what it is like. It is definitely not for everyone but I couldn’t put it down....more

title: The Rome Zoo
author: Janovjak, Pascal
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It took me awhile to warm to this book so 3 stars moved to 4 by the end. This has a quirky storyline and an oblique way of describing events that leftIt took me awhile to warm to this book so 3 stars moved to 4 by the end. This has a quirky storyline and an oblique way of describing events that left me feeling like I was on slippery ground understanding exactly what was going on. As the story unfurls and the characters become familiar I was able to enjoy the underlying humour. There was also a lot of commentary going on: - the purpose and establishing of zoos - I’m sure the descriptions of animal attrition and animal deaths (while fictional here) are probably grounded in reality.- the disturbing passion and obsession that people develop towards the tamandin (a fictional animal and the last of its species in the world) the need of people to control and dominate their environment - the rise and fall of the zoos fortunes, excesses and decay that align with Italy’s own century of history - the lengths that scientists (may) go to to achieve their own success ***- and this - “It hardy matters, since these days the role of journalism is first and foremost to prolong the reverberation of tragedy.” There’s also the characters personal stories of love and loss ebbing and flowing in the background.A genuine, unusual and thoughtful book....more

review: This book had me enthralled. I’ve never read a Thomas Mann novel and yet I was glued to the page. This is a family that pushed the boundaries in so maThis book had me enthralled. I’ve never read a Thomas Mann novel and yet I was glued to the page. This is a family that pushed the boundaries in so many directions.While the character of Mann talks about how he writes long convoluted sentences that hint and suggest Toibin writes with a style that conveys atmosphere and meaning with smooth easy to read narration. This is not to say this is simplistic, there is thoughtful analysis of the complex situation Mann was placed in - his heritage and love of German art, music and culture versus his despair at the blind acceptance of Hitler and his regime of terror. Mann often seemed to be caught in situations where he would be condemned regardless of his actions. Definitely recommended for anyone interested in 20th century European history and writers....more

title: Eyrie
author: Winton, Tim
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I thought this book felt familiar and that I may have read it previously and forgotten. I’ve now realised it is my own familiarity with the locations I thought this book felt familiar and that I may have read it previously and forgotten. I’ve now realised it is my own familiarity with the locations and Winton’s ability to uncompromisingly use local slang and descriptions in a way that is unique and specific. When he describes the Swan River ...” the water was brown and chunky as a dish full of steeping mushrooms “... I’m flashed back to ferry crossings on a river alive and soupy with jellyfish. The tension in this story brews with the fiercely hot long summer weather that is endemic to Perth. His protagonist , Tom, is trapped in a hopeless situation and his physical and mental health is spiralling out of control. This is Winton exploring the people and places on the grey sandy strip with an unwavering eye.This audiobook was also excellently narrated by Michael Veitch....more

review: From a non-American perspective I found the entwining of this time in US history with that of (what could have been) a typical family a very interestiFrom a non-American perspective I found the entwining of this time in US history with that of (what could have been) a typical family a very interesting way to approach this story. The complexity of how families dealt with (or actually didn’t) being on different sides of such a divisive topic was something that had not occurred to me. I was also surprised at how much racism and pro-slavery sentiment existed in the Union States - this probably explains (to me) a lot more about why progress for equality has been so slow.I have just read this novel back to back with Horse by Geraldine Brooks. I think Brooks managed to deal with racism and slavery (plus more) in a more successful and succinct manner. I felt Booth could have been pruned a little more without compromising this wonderful story. I think it was successful to portray the family from the point-of-view of the sisters as they were depicted as being more attached to family than the political issues and were both more constant and reliable witnesses of the events. Also there is probably less factual information about either of them which allowed Fowler freedom to explore their lives using fiction.I can’t see this as a Booker winner but it was certainly a worthwhile read....more

author: Doyle, Briohny
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Echolalia sounds like such a beautiful word but it is truely heartbreaking in this context. This story has left me reeling. The first third, about EmmEcholalia sounds like such a beautiful word but it is truely heartbreaking in this context. This story has left me reeling. The first third, about Emma, seemed like a small but desperately sad (and not unfamiliar in novels) domestic drama. In the middle third Doyle turns a sweeping lens on the characters around Emma and using a before and after narration technique we begin to see a darker story emerge. The final third again changes focus, looking at bigger world issues and how they impact upon the characters (and us all). In the closing stages we are drawn back to the heart of the matter. What can never be undone and the question of how to go on is all that remains. The clever use of “the woman “, “the girl” and “the man” made me feel that this was a story, that in some respects, includes us all in its landscape. ...more

review: This seemed like a series of momentous events that connected people through time and place - like a hall of mirrors - looking forward, backwards and sThis seemed like a series of momentous events that connected people through time and place - like a hall of mirrors - looking forward, backwards and sideways. I noticed recurring themes: flags, forbidden love, leaving and reinventing a life but I also felt a kind of empty vanishing at the end. Where did they go? Why did they leave the story? And what next? review: I really enjoyed this book and while you could read the two novellas separately it was interesting to ponder over the common ideas. There is also a lot of humour in these stories ( I laughed allowed at the names of streets and people), however the story of Lyle does take a very dark turn. This dark turn made me think of Richard Flanagan’s novel, The Living Sea of Waking Dreams. The themes of racism, colour and religion are explored in the past and a potential future. As Lyle and his wife, Chanel, suggest should immigrants obliterate their past in order to assimilate? What are the dangers? Ultimately I felt bot Lyle’s and Lily’s stories presented many questions about identity and the importance it plays in accepting and understanding who we are. title: Tenderness
author: MacLeod, Alison*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This book finishes with an exhilarating and page turning court case but wow… 593pages … it took me a long time to get there. A fascinating recreation This book finishes with an exhilarating and page turning court case but wow… 593pages … it took me a long time to get there. A fascinating recreation of the final days of D H Lawrence, the rise of JF Kennedy (through the eyes of Jackie), the mania and power of J Edgar Hoover through the eyes of an imagined agent and the British court case against Penguin books to ban the publication of Lady Chatterley’s Lover. This is a mid-century drama like no other. Macleod has clearly impeccably researched this period - the events and cultural challenges that faced a modernised world as well as the dismantling of Lawrence’s post World War 1 world - devastating and grim. Just providing a brief description like this will give you some idea of what is in this tome. This is really long, goes into extensive detail of settings, characters, people, side stories… I would have been happier with a shorter novel but I appreciate that this is half a century of events and the author had me totally immersed in them....more

review: There were some beautiful descriptions in this book but overall I felt detached from the characters, labour and setting. The detailed descriptions werThere were some beautiful descriptions in this book but overall I felt detached from the characters, labour and setting. The detailed descriptions were very specific and the big picture blurry. There were also a lot of characters that seemed to come and go before I knew them and outside the cloistered environment of the abbey I couldn’t envision the real world. I felt I needed to understand the circumstances of these women in order to care about them. This story seems to be an alternate reality ( that may have created a different gender dynamic or outlook) but in the end I don’t think that Marie’s world was entirely generous - rather it felt self serving. Her journey from impoverished outcast to powerful leader also happened without many obstacles. They were easily brushed aside.I’ve probably been overly critical here as the writing did include sentences that were evocative but it was just not the story for me....more

In the end you might even realise that it is the idea of a dream house and the people and conversations it might contain that you really want and not the actual house. review: I’m so glad I stumbled across a mention of this author by The London Review of Books. This novel provides a unique perspective of Germany during the rI’m so glad I stumbled across a mention of this author by The London Review of Books. This novel provides a unique perspective of Germany during the rise of the Nazi party. Living as a banned writer in Germany must have been a nerve wracking existence if you chose to continue criticism of the regime. This novel is written in a style that captures both the frenetic and increasingly absurd behaviour of those who try to elevate their political position and those who try to hide information that will cause them difficulties. The writing is darkly humorous but also conveys a serious dose of fear. Reading about the author’s life (an interesting epilogue at the end of this version of the text) also gave valuable context for this story....more

review: I loved this and I just want to eat the food from The Happy Fig restaurant. This does have a sad underlying atmosphere (particularly because there areI loved this and I just want to eat the food from The Happy Fig restaurant. This does have a sad underlying atmosphere (particularly because there are so many truths and real events that it is based on). Ultimately it does end with hope and possibility for repair of Cyprus and its people. This type of internal war must be so devastating- imagine war with your neighbours, colleagues, friends. This story also strongly reminds us of the inter generational impact that follows unspeakable events. The use of the fig tree as a narrator provides opportunity to act as a witness for events and crimes that would otherwise be unresolved. It must be unbearably sad for families to never uncover the truth about ‘missing’ family- which is basically a euphemism for murdered. This book gave me the same sort of feeling as Sarah Winman’s novel Still Life. …Oh and did I say the food is the best....more

review: 3.5 stars. Burnet is so clever at this style of novel (like His Bloody Project). Using ‘found’ documents to recreate a historical novel like this is v3.5 stars. Burnet is so clever at this style of novel (like His Bloody Project). Using ‘found’ documents to recreate a historical novel like this is very immersive and feels totally plausible. Braithwaite, his protagonist, is an extremely unlikeable character and it was difficult to feel any empathy for him. The star of this novel was his other protagonist, “Rebecca”. The humour her character imparts (a scene in a bar was particularly good) and her unraveling personality provide a perfect foil for the sparse matter of fact recount of Braithwaite’s rise and fall in the world of psychiatry. It almost felt like the psychiatric sessions caused “Rebecca” to descend into a mental health crisis that felt something like severe depression and a split personality rolled into one. This was an intriguing way to examine the ‘hit and miss’ development of psychiatry. There must have been a lot of casualties along the way....more

I don’t really know… The narrator really wants L (the artist) to paint her and capture her identity… and he says he wants to destroy her. I’m not sure what sort of relationship this is. I did think the commentary on living in the present and not being obsessed with the future was creatively portrayed through this Second Place. I liked the descriptions of marsh, tide and seasons which captured this ebb and flow of time passing, cycling and the interconnectedness of the people who live there. ...more

title: Bewilderment
author: Powers, Richard
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This novel left me traversed by a confusion of feelings and questions. Richard Powers skilfully dives deeply into the human condition and our desire fThis novel left me traversed by a confusion of feelings and questions. Richard Powers skilfully dives deeply into the human condition and our desire for answers and labels - I didn’t disappoint him :) As a species we feel the need to understand everything, and in this novel the inner mind proves as unknowable as the outer reaches of the universe. Meanwhile our home planet is on a trajectory that requires immediate attention and Robin (our narrator, Theo’s son) is desperate to bring this to the forefront of public attention. At first Power’s leads you to assume (well I felt he did) that Robin is neuro diverse ( ...has autism, on the spectrum? ) and a simple conclusion, that his father refuses to accept, would be to medicate him. Slowly it becomes apparent that his behaviour is not quite so simple and also reflects serious trauma.Is the treatment that Theo chooses to pursue more ethical? I loved the planets that Theo imagines for his son. They are as diverse as the human race and again a question... how do we judge the success or value of life on another planet OR another human? Is being homogeneous really the goal? So many other themes: political overreach, loss, parenting, climate change, impact of social media, privacy... ...more

author: Morgan, Joyce*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: 4.5 stars. A biography that is both enchanting and engaging. This book weaves together the life of a fascinating woman with European historical events4.5 stars. A biography that is both enchanting and engaging. This book weaves together the life of a fascinating woman with European historical events and the modern literary movement of England, providing the reader with a rich contextual framework (from a particular perspective) of the late 19th and early 20th century. Mary Beauchamp (Countess von Arnim, Elizabeth von Arnim or the Countess Russell - depending on the time period of her life!) was an extraordinary, independent and resourceful feminist of her times. I have read two of her novels, Vera and The Enchanted April, and would certainly like to read more. How her novels reflect moments of her real life create a new level of interest and intrigue in how she portrayed fictional characters. I was continually stopping to check connections between people and places. This also led me to want to expand my reading on a number of other authors, including Katherine Mansfield, D H Lawrence and H.G. Wells.While there is plenty of detail in this biography I felt Morgan enabled the reader to keep track of people, locations and events by revisiting and reminding the reader without being overly repetitious....more

title: A Passage North
author: Arudpragasam, Anuk*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This novel is a metaphysical journey that coincides with Krishan’s physical train trip to attend the funeral of his grandmother’s carer. Through KrishThis novel is a metaphysical journey that coincides with Krishan’s physical train trip to attend the funeral of his grandmother’s carer. Through Krishan’s thoughts and memories Arudpragasam explores the inaccessibility of human minds with particular focus on the impact of trauma and ageing on a persons ability to live with and within their own mind.“…but people also carried deeper, more clandestine trajectories inside their bodies, their origins often unknown or accidental, their modes of operation invisible to the eye, trajectories which were sometimes strong enough to push people in certain directions despite everything that took place on the surface of their lives.”The writing toward the beginning of this novel, when Krishan describes his grandmothers deterioration as she ages and her desperate struggle to maintain dignity and autonomy, felt so real and accurate. It is difficult/sad to watch and live with ageing family members and this was captured perfectly.Another recurring theme was the importance of our eyes; the window to our souls, the sights once seen that cannot be erased and the awful scene of eye gouging and blinding. This is a thought provoking story that attempts to explore humanity and the complexity of the mind. It is slow and it wanders so it certainly may not be to everyone’s taste....more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: 4.5 stars. Imagine having an adult child that has committed a serious crime. What is your responsibility, guilt or reaction? Lohrey examines this trau4.5 stars. Imagine having an adult child that has committed a serious crime. What is your responsibility, guilt or reaction? Lohrey examines this trauma with delicate and thoughtful care. Erica is struggling to maintain her present because she can’t see what the future will hold for her and her son. She seems completely undone by his actions.The other characters similarly seem to be living with past trauma. Erica’s labyrinth is a tangible anchor to the earth and the present for all of them.This book gives you an odd feeling of familiarity while simultaneously you are struck by what you don’t know. The setting is very Australian...coastal...near Sydney... but the exact location feels deliberately unknowable and disorientating. The characters are living in the present but there are glimpses of their past that leave you wanting more.In some respects this reminded me of The Museum of Modern Love by Heather Rose. The use of art, the power of communal healing and compassion while focusing on the present in order to find an acceptable future....more

review: This novel has vivid and powerful descriptions of a Scottish town that is struggling to hold onto its past glory and good times and is now a place wheThis novel has vivid and powerful descriptions of a Scottish town that is struggling to hold onto its past glory and good times and is now a place where life is difficult, money is hard to come by and young people have few life choices or opportunities. In comes a catholic priest, Father David, who is an outsider and facing his own crisis about his life choices - you can feel that his world is about to implode. Despite his unacceptable actions and his somewhat pompous behaviour I still felt some empathy for him because he was able to acknowledge his wrongs. This book was able to create a realistic three dimensional world with all its problematic flaws and provoke thoughts about how we judge people when we don’t know their life circumstances and what it means to belong or be an outsider in a community....more

title: The Lamplighters
author: Stonex, Emma*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: So good... grief, guilt, loneliness in a taut well paced mystery. The descriptions of the lighthouse, ocean and the light keepers that live in these ISo good... grief, guilt, loneliness in a taut well paced mystery. The descriptions of the lighthouse, ocean and the light keepers that live in these Isolated inhospitable locations is beautifully imagined. I also felt the changing perspectives and point-of-views for each character were collated in a clever and varied way that helped to immerse the reader in this story. The choice to only include one side of many of the conversations was superb as it felt like this story was circling those people directly involved in the disappearance of the three men. This heightened the stakes and added to the tension. This included how the interviews were conducted by ‘the writer’ trying to piece together the story and ‘the company’ interviews of the wives after the event. This is definitely one of my favourites on the longlist for The Women’s Prize for Fiction (that I’ve read) and I hope it makes the shortlist....more

review: “I am envious of these people. Their ability to accept absence of evidence as evidence of absence. “This book explores the infinite capacity of the hu“I am envious of these people. Their ability to accept absence of evidence as evidence of absence. “This book explores the infinite capacity of the human brain to embrace, manipulate and mould beliefs and ideas. When people have a sense of purpose and justification for their beliefs this helps them to make sense of the world. Every person needs to believe in something in order to rationalise the world around them. Sometimes this means people move to a place where their beliefs transition from providing ‘safety’ (as described by James Baldwin) , familiarity, comfort and sanity to a place of control, isolation and narrow mindedness.Krasnostein thoughtfully meanders through a number of lives examining how people arrive at their beliefs, why they choose to hold them and the impact this has on them as individuals and a community.The choice of Krasnostien’s subjects may have been influenced by her own living arrangements (that sounds a bit weird- I mean living in Australia and USA) but she has still managed to cover a broad range of topics that are melded together in an interesting and accessible way....more

The chapters set in occupied Palestine were heartbreaking. It is hard to imagine how any group of people that have themselves been persecuted can so quickly become persecutors of others. review: Madeleine Watts captures the bleak despair that accompanies a life that seems adrift and without purpose - a young women wondering what is next. Her sMadeleine Watts captures the bleak despair that accompanies a life that seems adrift and without purpose - a young women wondering what is next. Her summer is fuelled by a seemingly self destructive tendency despite her own awareness of the cost of her behaviour. Watts looks back into the past through explorers like Oxley - have we always sought what is imagined - like an inland sea? Through a hot Sydney summer, where there is a sense of foreboding, climate change sparks an increased threat of fires and alcohol fuels violence. The abduction and murder that Watts repeatedly refers to was an event that shocked and caught national media attention in Australia and drove home the fear that we are all vulnerable to such violence. It came amidst a swathe of horrific domestic abuse situations, that seem to continue despite the public conversations and campaigns to end it. I wasn’t completely satisfied by the ending of this novel but overall it was compelling and sharp....more

review: This is a relentless and devastating reconstruction of numerous events across the Middle East that have resulted in loss of liberty and home, devastatThis is a relentless and devastating reconstruction of numerous events across the Middle East that have resulted in loss of liberty and home, devastation, starvation, imprisonment and death for the civilian populations of numerous countries. Using her first hand experience and investigative journalistic skills McNeill carefully explains how despotic leaders, ambivalence and greed continue to see millions of people displaced or living under tyranny. This book made me feel despair, horror and rage (which I could also sense directly from McNeill during her reading of this audio book).While I was aware of many of the individual events that she recounted I wasn’t aware of many of the connections between events. I am also aware of how much misinformation is circulated by governments with vested interests. How we choose to vote for our politicians is often the only direct way we can sway our own government response to these issues and it will definitely be something I will continue to do. There are some truely horrific crimes being perpetrated and I feel so sad....more

review: Growing up as a black girl from a poor family in the 60’s and 70’s in Rhodesia provides a backdrop for this novel but it explores much more than colonGrowing up as a black girl from a poor family in the 60’s and 70’s in Rhodesia provides a backdrop for this novel but it explores much more than colonialism. The patriarchal system, poverty and religion are all issues that have created turmoil for Tambu, the young narrator. How to improve her future and opportunities without compromising the values she has been brought up to respect is a constant feature of her inner monologue. Even her cousin Nhamo who has lived overseas and has come from a much wealthier background does not have an easy life. In fact, hers may be more challenging because her father is the revered figurehead for the entire family. This is a quiet but striking novel that asks and challenges the reader to question expectations and traditions in the light of a changing world....more

author: Murgia, Michela
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A deceptively simple story of a young girl growing up in a small 1950’s Sardinian community. Deceptive because it deals with big issues. Maria the 4thA deceptively simple story of a young girl growing up in a small 1950’s Sardinian community. Deceptive because it deals with big issues. Maria the 4th daughter of a local widow is ‘given’ to another woman, Bonaria, to raise. She still lives in the same community as her birth mother and three older sisters (she’s the discard) and is expected to just accept this situation. They refer to these children (because apparently this is not an uncommon practice) as a ‘child of the soul’. This however is not the central controversial theme. Bonaria (Maria’s adoptive mum) has a special place in the community as a person who can assist death - this is not a spoiler - the word Accabadora is a character from Sardinian folklore known as the lady of the Good Death. How Bonaria carries out this job, makes decisions, and maintains secrecy from Maria (who completely trusts her ) is what makes this story special and heart wrenching.This was listed as one of Elena Ferrante’s top reads which is what led me to track it down. An atmospheric and delicate novel that captures a certain place and time and the people that inhabit it....more

title: The White Earth
author: McGahan, Andrew
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: An emotive story with a grim secret at its core. This book explores the history and struggle of early white settlement in outback Queensland and the  An emotive story with a grim secret at its core. This book explores the history and struggle of early white settlement in outback Queensland and the cost to the original inhabitants. Primarily set during the time of the High court decisions on Mabo and Terra Nullius this novel explores the exploitation, exposure and fear that surrounded the outcomes. Many landowners had seized land and driven out indigenous inhabitants (or worse) for their own profit. This is also a coming of age story as Will is forced to come to understand and come to terms with the violence of his ancestors and the implications for his future. McGahan does an excellent job tackling a complex and difficult subject....more

title: Infinite Splendours
author: Laguna, Sofie
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: 2.5 stars. I found this a really disturbing read and I don’t think it needed to make me feel uncomfortable in the way it did to achieve a conversation2.5 stars. I found this a really disturbing read and I don’t think it needed to make me feel uncomfortable in the way it did to achieve a conversation about abuse. The first half of the book, about Lawrence’s childhood, was powerful and engaging. Lawrence, as the first person narrator and protagonist, allowed me to develop a sense of who he was and what a thoughtful young person he was becoming. While he suffered horrific abuse the writing still drew me in and I felt it would be a powerful book. Unfortunately the second half of the book seemed to circle and repeat endlessly while not moving forward. While I understand that this trauma would have lifetime implications I didn’t think this would include him showing no intellectual growth (he was extremely bright). I accepted his choice for isolation and the physical changes that occurred to him. However despite being inside his head and thoughts his internal monologue revealed little. I also didn’t find the theme of art engaging. I just felt like I was reading an endless list of artists and their artwork without really understanding their connection to Lawrence or the moment he was mentioning them. The trajectory of Lawrence’s life took on such a disturbing path in the second half of the novel and his choices for pursuing secrecy with other young people repulsed me which also meant I lost all empathy for his character. While I accept that stories do not need a happy resolution this felt soulless.. The best moment in this novel was when the brothers climbed the mountain. The descriptions were lovely and the rising tension was crystal clear at this moment. By the way can anyone explain why he ended up hating his brother so much?I’m sorry for the harsh  because I really liked Laguna’s previous novels...more

title: Song of the Crocodile
author: Simpson, Nardi
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Each generation starts with innocence and optimism but ends crushed by a system and sadness that feels totally overwhelming. As Mili and her family atEach generation starts with innocence and optimism but ends crushed by a system and sadness that feels totally overwhelming. As Mili and her family attempt to make do and compromise they are continually thwarted by an agenda to drive them out. This is a very sad book with small moments of happiness. Simpson has created an image of a town that will smother every opportunity for happiness with bigotry, racism and lies. Sadly, It felt very real.You can feel the earth (or that crocodile like creature that lives within it) rising up to fight back. It reminded me of the character of Dead Papa Toothwort from Max Porter’s book, Lanny. The trajectory of Paddy’s life seems doomed despite the love of his family. The characters of this novel, both good and bad, are well written and Simpson has captured small nuances that bring them to life. I loved the images of departed loved ones looking down on their family and working together to support them from afar. It showed the connections that exist across generation and place.My only small criticism is that the mayor becomes the representation of evil in Darnmoor. This feel like an overused trope. Mili’s fate seemed obvious (to me anyway) from the moment his character was introduced.This novel has a beautiful sense of place. The descriptions of life and landscape on the river plain are evocative and a highlight of this moving story....more
