title: Imperial Intimacies: A Tale of Two Islands
author: Carby, Hazel V.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Carby uses extensive historical research and family folklore to imagine conversations, reconstruct the unfolding of events and create a picture of herCarby uses extensive historical research and family folklore to imagine conversations, reconstruct the unfolding of events and create a picture of her family history, and that of two islands. A history that pits her British ancestors, as beneficiaries of imperial theft and privileges, against her black Jamaican ancestors. She weaves a tale that is confronting in examining the cost of white privilege and how it became ingrained in every facet of British life, even for those who themselves struggled with a life of poverty.It is also her reckoning with a difficult family life and childhood and the prejudices placed on her parent’s marriage. As a ‘brown’ child stigma and pressures were placed on herself and her mother while her father faced continual resistance in his attempts to achieve recognition of his place in British society ( as a war veteran and citizen) and employment commensurate with his ability. “ From the depths of her melancholia my mother would summon Beatrice (-her mother) into her kitchen as if recruiting an ally in her battle to forge a perfect daughter. But the daughter Iris yearned for was not meant to be a writer who strayed beyond the tales she received: I was not meant to be curious; I was not meant to burrow beneath their plots; and I was not meant to undermine their narrative foundations, disrupting their silences, excavating what had been so assiduously hidden,” This book has some brilliant and insightful writing on colonialism and the ‘power’ of empire.  “British political, social and economic generosity was understood to have been embodied first in the abolition of the slave trade and, second, in the unstinting imperial labour to bring civilization and enlightenment to a third of the globe. This selfless mission was undermined when the empire came home. Boatloads of coloured immigrants, who had the nerve to think they were British, betrayed the spirit and practices of English liberalism. Having landed on the shores of a kind-hearted and generous-spirited Island, they just didn’t know how to behave like decent English people.”There were a couple of chapters I didn’t find quite so compelling- the descriptions of double entry accounting (for obvious reasons!). I also found the recount of Carby’s Jamaican family a bit difficult to follow. It wasn’t as fleshed out (probably due to lack of available evidence) and I got confused with all the different family names and connections. It became a bit ‘list like’ rather than a narrative.I can’t remember where I saw a recommendation for this book - perhaps on a list by Bernadine Evaristo? Anyway it is definitely worthwhile and recommended if you are interested in the impact of empire, colonialism or the slave trade....more

review: It was a privilege to read this book by Sudbanthad and explore the history of Bangkok (Krungthep to the locals). It’s a city I have visited a number oIt was a privilege to read this book by Sudbanthad and explore the history of Bangkok (Krungthep to the locals). It’s a city I have visited a number of times over the past thirty years and it always offers something wonderful and unexpected. The reader does need to work for this story. Each new chapter throws you with time shifts and characters that are revisited, woven and interconnected in the space that exists between recurring floods and political upheveals. This city is very much alive. As Sudbanthad says it’s “the messy business of the living and breathing.”There is sadness in the loss of home, family, opportunity and relationships and, in the birds that call Krungthep home in its very early days but are seen returning in the imagined future. It’s a place that pulls people home and speaks to them from distant lands. Sammy is a character running away but never escaping and Née is a character finding peace. Everything and nothing is the same....more

review: Daisy Johnson once again exhibits her ability to examine difficult family relationships that push people to the brink. In Sisters it is all about coerDaisy Johnson once again exhibits her ability to examine difficult family relationships that push people to the brink. In Sisters it is all about coercive control. How can you simultaneously love and hate another person so entirely ?This story keeps you hanging for the truth. You know something is wrong but it’s difficult to pinpoint. For an outsider in a relationship this must be much like how subversive control appears. I also think ‘The Settle House’, where much of this story is set, is the linch pin that holds it together. Like the interior of the mind it a place where you are trapped. It is a foreboding character, a place of memories and perhaps (eventual) a place to ‘settle’ or find a resolution.If you liked Johnson’s previous novel, Everything Under, I think you will also appreciate this novel. title: The Shadow King
author: Mengiste, Maaza
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This was a fascinating and beautifully poetic story about a truely horrific war of invasion. The mesmerising language brings beauty and shows love forThis was a fascinating and beautifully poetic story about a truely horrific war of invasion. The mesmerising language brings beauty and shows love for the Ethiopian people and its landscape. Mengiste sheds a powerful light on the women who fought to repel Mussolini’s invaders and protect their fellow countryman. They put themselves at considerable risk, not only from the enemy but also the men they fought alongside. This invasion was viewed from the perspective of both the invaders and the invaded creating a rich tapestry of perspectives, motives and emotions. However it was the impact of patriarchy on all of the characters that kept drawing my attention. Kidane, Hirut, Ettore, Aster, Fucelli and even Emperor Haile Selassie all responded and reflected on their patrilineal relationships as a driving force in their need to seek power, control others, produce offspring and seek some sort of compensation for the ‘damage’ or failure of their own ability to live up to expectations placed upon them. The damage and havoc of this system reverberates through the generations.This year’s Booker Prize will be a tough choice with so many big powerful stories....more

review: I don’t know where to begin with this book because there is so much to explore and think about. It’s emotionally extremely intense and after the firstI don’t know where to begin with this book because there is so much to explore and think about. It’s emotionally extremely intense and after the first half I progressed in small chunks. Ora, Avram and Ofer have a complex inter-relationship of love, friendship and guilt. Their lives are completely entwined in a way that has them permanently dependent on each other but also unable to bear each other’s company. The section of the book where we relive Avram awaiting capture is heartbreaking. It is easy to imagine why Ora has taken herself away from home to hide from any news while her son serves his final military service. I also thought about the senseless of war and the impact of this on families and individuals. Each valley, mountain or monument that is inscribed with a memorial to a lost child wears away at your hope that this will ever end. The unfairness and suspicion with which the Palestinians are treated and how everyone appears to shut down their emotional intelligence in order to live through another day is harrowing.This is definitely a book that is worth reading but only if you are prepared to put in the time....more

review: 4 1/2 stars. This is a crazy novel and I loved it. It has a cast of warm, slightly bizarre characters who will take you on a wild and somewhat illegal4 1/2 stars. This is a crazy novel and I loved it. It has a cast of warm, slightly bizarre characters who will take you on a wild and somewhat illegal romp through 1960’s south Brooklyn. Imagine an elderly drunk man known as Sportscoat who talks to his deceased wife, shoots a young drug dealer and then doesn’t remember the incident! The shooting triggers a feud amongst the local mafia groups who are vying for control of the neighbourhood. As they scramble for control a central message emerges “A person who trusts can be trusted”. The local community are resilient, funny, sad and savvy as they negotiate looking after each other and saving their home. The sad part of this story is the inevitability of drugs infiltrating the community, destroying the lives of its youth and the corruption of those with power. It’s a delicate balance to examine this sensitively and McBride has done this well....more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Recently some universities in Australia have been gifting their new undergraduates with a book at the beginning of their first academic year. This booRecently some universities in Australia have been gifting their new undergraduates with a book at the beginning of their first academic year. This book should be on this list and it should be compulsory reading. It’s too easy to say that domestic abuse is unstoppable, victims choose to remain in abusive relationships, the problem isn’t really that bad or we already have a legal system to deal with this problem. Domestic abuse effects us all and Jess Hill discusses this rationally and with clarity. She identifies the collective responsibility we need to have and discusses some of the approaches that could become part of a toolkit to reduce the frequency and escalation of violence.While this book includes descriptions that are difficult to read it is never gratuitous. Understanding the complexity of the problem, current strategies for dealing with domestic abuse and possible alternatives are all part of Hill’s approach to opening our eyes and creating a conversation we need to have....more

review: Absolutely brilliant. In a short exacting novel Ginsburg decisively creates complex characters. Her language and sentence structure are deceptively siAbsolutely brilliant. In a short exacting novel Ginsburg decisively creates complex characters. Her language and sentence structure are deceptively simple (like Sally Rooney). As a reader you are able to join the dots without having to be ‘told’ how to interpret events. Events, mostly, unfold through letters that are written back and forth between the main characters. There is also a good dose of humour in these chaotic people as they reveal themselves and each other (she’s possibly a writer that has inspired Ferrante). I’ll definitely be exploring more of her writing....more

When your whole novel hinges on one climatic conclusion it is tricky to negotiate pace and to keep the reader interested in incidental events along the way. Sally Piper has managed to sustain the tempo and explore the three main characters personalities in a convincing way. My only hesitation is that I’m not sure if these characters changed or developed sufficiently to justify the wait. Maybe their transformation is actually learning to accept themselves for who they are but I’m not sure this is the intention. review: This was a book in two parts - for me. The first half was compelling and continually opened new doors, revealing fragments of Katherine’s life and theThis was a book in two parts - for me. The first half was compelling and continually opened new doors, revealing fragments of Katherine’s life and the mystery of Nora’s paternity. Suddenly, just after the half way mark the circling and revisiting of events occurred frequently but the revelation of new information slowed considerably. While the final chapters and conclusion were satisfactory I think a chunk of the second half did not add value to the plot or the characters. The writing is provocative and the descriptions are sharp throughout the novel but I began to get a bit frustrated because I had so many questions about why Katherine had become so self destructive? review: I really enjoyed the narrative style of this book which included the first person plural as ‘we the community ‘. We watch events unfold in Oak Knoll, I really enjoyed the narrative style of this book which included the first person plural as ‘we the community ‘. We watch events unfold in Oak Knoll, North Carolina over the period of a few months with flashbacks to fill in the gaps and understand the motives of our characters. On either side of this narration the reader is able to visit the two families at the centre of the drama. In this way we can see events as they unfold, are misconstrued and manipulated. This is, as our narrator reminds us, a cautionary tale about prejudice and I was thoroughly hooked....more

review: If you’ve read My Sister the Serial Killer I would describe this as the next level of horrific violence and definitely more black than humour. ThroughIf you’ve read My Sister the Serial Killer I would describe this as the next level of horrific violence and definitely more black than humour. Through a community of individual narrators, giving eye witness testimonies, we circle around the Cuban neighbourhood of Cienfuegos delving into the dark actions and motives of its inhabitants. The centre piece of this community is a cathedral that is being constructed to unite people but this plan seems very much doomed to failure. While it took me awhile to establish each cast member, as they have multiple names, this is an important structural technique that works really well to reveal the hierarchy that exists between them. This is a definite contender for the International Booker Prize list for its unflinching portrayal of modern Cuba and cleverly constructed plot....more

review: Ever since the first “Raiders of the Lost Ark” I’ve been a sucker for mysteries set in the Amazon jungle so it’s not surprising this story hooked me.AEver since the first “Raiders of the Lost Ark” I’ve been a sucker for mysteries set in the Amazon jungle so it’s not surprising this story hooked me.A scientist has died mysteriously after being sent to the Amazon to investigate a research project being conducted by a ‘rogue’ scientist in an unknown location. A second scientist, his work colleague and a former student of the ‘rogue’ scientist, has been sent to get answers about her colleague’s death and determine the progress of the research project. Things are clearly much more complex than they seem and Patchett skilfully ramps up the tension in this bug infested and inhospitable environment. This novel throws up lots of questions about the ethics of research on vulnerable communities and the environment but is also highly entertaining....more

review: This is an outstanding book and a triumph in it’s construction. While it is very ‘on trend’ to create hybrid style books Apeirogon does this in a way This is an outstanding book and a triumph in it’s construction. While it is very ‘on trend’ to create hybrid style books Apeirogon does this in a way that value adds to the story it imparts. It’s like picking up the shards of a shattered mirror, examining them - some are sharp and cutting, others are just fragments and could fit anywhere - but together they reflect a whole complex story. This book brings to life the multifaceted lives of those who live under and around occupation and the sadness, fear, misinformation and disparity this inflicts. It delves into the silence between sounds and to the birds that fly across it’s borders and are not constrained by political boundaries.I think that McCann has indeed created a memorable work of art.“Ullmann had once written that the secret of every work of art was the annihilation of matter through form.”...more

What I did like was imagining how all the animals might actually sound and the cacophony of noise that would surround us if they really could communicate. While there were moments of humour this didn’t become the fantastical ride that I was hoping for.**** I have just listened to the audio of this and I found it more enjoyable than reading it myself. review: 3 1/2 stars. Thank you Better Reading for my Advance Proof.Evie Wyld has created a sweep of vivid flawed women struggling to battle through the disapp3 1/2 stars. Thank you Better Reading for my Advance Proof.Evie Wyld has created a sweep of vivid flawed women struggling to battle through the disappointment of disrespectful and violent relationships. Despite living hundreds of years apart they all become victims, under different circumstances, of men. This is a reminder that physical violence and psychological abuse continue to happen and this book explores the many ways it is perpetrated on women.The use of bass rock as a connector for the stories provided a dramatic unsettling backdrop for the unfolding events. I also liked the slightly speculative feel created by ghosts of women past and the camaraderie of women helping each other. My favourite scene was ‘the beach picnic’ - this was a gothic and frightening moment with superb tension.I liked the different time periods and I’m generally okay with shifting time frames but I would have preferred a better marker or indicator as I found the Roman numerals confusing. A small icon or logo connected with each time period would have made it easier to follow. Overall the impact of parts of this novel was more powerful than its entirety which had so many interesting but unresolved threads....more

review: 4 1/2 stars. Zamani, the narrator of this story, is a deeply unpleasant character who is trying his best to manipulate his way into the lives of Abedn4 1/2 stars. Zamani, the narrator of this story, is a deeply unpleasant character who is trying his best to manipulate his way into the lives of Abednego and Mama Agnes. He has befriended their son, Bukhosi, who has disappeared in mysterious circumstances and he is now plying Abednego with alcohol and drugs in order to get him to talk about his family hi-story and preying on Agnes’s desperation to find her son. The revelations that they share with Zamani propel the reader through the pre and post independence era of Zimbabwe and exposes the corruption, murder and rape that left people damaged and struggling to determine their identity. “I too have lived through the dread of the glint of recognition. Of having to stare into a face and be faced with the truth of your own face.”This is a complex and powerful story. It did take me awhile to sink into but then there was no turning back. review: I requested this book from the library and by the time it arrived I had forgotten how I had come across it...funny how that happens. This story was wrI requested this book from the library and by the time it arrived I had forgotten how I had come across it...funny how that happens. This story was written in 1925 and it’s strength lies in the author’s personal experience during this interwar time period in Far Eastern Europe, his childhood and military career having occurred there. This time period is a turbulent mix of nations regrouping and asserting themselves after WW1 and this is combined with internal upheaval in Russia. While I’m sure I missed subtle (and possibly not so subtle) ironic stabs I enjoyed Gerhardie’s fictional Belgian family caught up in the midst of these events. Definitely not a Russian family saga!While some parts of this story rolled along with quirky humour and observations (Where did the 1000 missing fur hats ever end up going?) other parts felt a bit repetitive. This story is narrated by the self absorbed young Georges and his sexism and some racist comments may grate a little on contemporary readers but it is probably a genuine reflection of the time. ...more

review: This is an outstanding debut novel and represents the growth and direction of Australian contemporary writing. The diversity of voices, landscapes andThis is an outstanding debut novel and represents the growth and direction of Australian contemporary writing. The diversity of voices, landscapes and social issues are realistic and well crafted. As each of the early chapters follows a different character in unrelated locations and circumstances I did have to check to confirm that I wasn’t reading a book of short stories. It was a bit disorientating and it took me awhile to sink into the next ‘story’. As the book progressed and characters were revisited over unidentified timespans the overall picture began to emerge. This book examines how trauma and grief associated with war, and the loss of connection to place and people impacts on individuals, families and communities. The topic of early onset dementia was also handled well as it explored survivors guilt and the helplessness of the condition. ...more

As the US plunged into the money and excitement of the twenty first century the risk of losing everything and becoming forgotten as quickly as you became known was a strong possibility. In a modern take this idea continues to circle us with the rate of technological progress and short lived fame meaning that celebrity status and fame can be a very short lived thing. review: I think the strength and originality in this story definitely lay in the use of the dictionary of indigenous language used as a device to narrate the I think the strength and originality in this story definitely lay in the use of the dictionary of indigenous language used as a device to narrate the history of this fictional place through the eyes of August’s grandfather. After recently reading ‘Dark Emu’ by Bill Pascoe I feel that ‘The Yield’ may have been influenced by this. Winch has created a composite fictional place that explores similar content to Pascoe’s research (but in a fictional unique way) about indigenous farming methods, social interactions and lifestyle. This felt like a strong overlap (but maybe I only noticed it because I have read Dark Emu so recently). Another novel with similar themes was Melissa Lukashenko’s ‘Too Much Lip’ which I really enjoyed for its humour and matter of factness. These novels continue to raise the profile of some skilful and creative indigenous writers and explore new ways to present Australian history and contemporary cultural stereotypes....more

review: 3 1/2 stars. Set in Oman, through a period of tumultuous change, during the 19th and 20th century this book explores the impact of religion, slavery, 3 1/2 stars. Set in Oman, through a period of tumultuous change, during the 19th and 20th century this book explores the impact of religion, slavery, gun trafficking, war, invasion and modernisation on the extended family of Abdallah. The changes faced by each generation brings new challenges as Oman and it’s people are forced to adapt - some better than others. This family saga has two perspectives in alternating chapters and has lots of time shifts. This did make it tricky to follow and I would have been lost without the family tree at the front of the book. Abdallah narrates in the first person and reflects on his life through one strand and the alternating chapter in the third person moves between all of the extended family, basically moving forward from the arranged wedding of Mayya and Abdallah.This was a great introduction to Oman and provided interesting insights into a country and people that are clearly proud of their identity but struggle to retain it under the pressure of globalisation and external influences. The Man Booker International prize do a great job in bringing translated books, such as this, to a broader international audience....more

review: “ I had long known that the more simple a thing was, the less likely it was to be understood...” This pretty much sums up the relationship that exists“ I had long known that the more simple a thing was, the less likely it was to be understood...” This pretty much sums up the relationship that exists between Emerence and the narrator; both women with strong ideologies and inflexible habits. This is a striking portrait of two women with a strange affinity for each other. It’s a story set post WWII where many people had survived but witnessed events and kept secrets which haunted them. This novel explores the difficulty of trust and what it really means to be Christian in the Hungary that emerged during this time.I think Szabo has skilfully played with the readers sympathies and allegiances to these women. As events unravel and we discover their personal histories I felt myself shift in knowing who I should trust and who I felt empathy for....more

review: 3 1/2 stars. A disturbing story about the effect of war and trauma on childhood and memory. I do wonder whether the author knew where she was taking t3 1/2 stars. A disturbing story about the effect of war and trauma on childhood and memory. I do wonder whether the author knew where she was taking this story when she wrote the first of this trilogy? The first book is a much more straightforward, although graphically disturbing, but the the second and third books turn the reality of what you have previously read on its head. By the end you realise the unreliable narrator/s is a deeply traumatised individual recreating a story he can live with ( a bit like Life of Pi). What I found difficult to believe was the language and thought processes with which the author represented the behaviour of very young children. Perhaps this was deliberate but it didn’t quite work for me.I think this book reflects an aftermath of damaged people that existed long after the fighting stopped.“I say, ‘I don’t want to. I’d rather play with your children.’My brother says, ‘My children don’t play.’‘What do they do?’‘They are preparing to make it through life.’I say, ‘I made it through life and haven’t found anything.’My brother says, ‘there’s nothing to find. review: This is a devastating story about flawed humanity, family relationships and the consequences of abused trust. This is an amazing first novel by MadhurThis is a devastating story about flawed humanity, family relationships and the consequences of abused trust. This is an amazing first novel by Madhuri Vijay. The characters in this novel are complex and compelling and I felt invested in their futures. The fictional world revealed to us allows for the discussion of crimes that are clearly not entirely safe to discuss in a non-fiction format. I’m left thinking about how, in places like Kashmir, we make so many assumptions about what is happening based on the narrow funnel of news we are given and also how easy it is to manipulate our views and intentions. title: Dyschronia
author: Mills, Jennifer*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: While speculative fiction is not my favourite genre the writing in this novel has really pushed me as a reader and created something thought provokingWhile speculative fiction is not my favourite genre the writing in this novel has really pushed me as a reader and created something thought provoking.Reimagining the future using climate change and extinction needed something new and the disappearing sea provides this disturbing twist. As the town declines and the residents become increasingly desperate to find value in the place they call home a dark purpose is alluded to and unseen bureaucrats pull strings beyond their control. The multiple perspectives and multiple timelines are reasonably common in recent literature but I’m not sure I’ve seen the use of the first person ‘we’ before. While I did get a bit confused by some of these shifts, and perhaps there were a few too many, I think viewing the events as a townsfolk perspective was very clever and worked well. The cephalopod as creature that can morph and camouflage with its surroundings was a brilliant metaphor for how people can also disguise their intentions and modify their behaviour. The characters in this novel were multi layered and deceptive in much the same way.The visual and olfactory images created in this novel linger on as a dire warning. In a time where destruction of the planet is happening at such a rapid rate perhaps it does feel like we are living in the past, present and future simultaneously....more

review: 3 1/2 stars. At first this seems like a happy suburban drama. A neat recently finished street with houses full of wholesome civic minded families in 13 1/2 stars. At first this seems like a happy suburban drama. A neat recently finished street with houses full of wholesome civic minded families in 1960 USA. Slowly it reveals itself as we glimpse behind the doors and into the daily lives of these families. It’s a dark place of prejudice, domestic violence and jealousy where even those who appear happy are not.Alice Hoffman is great at describing daily life with a forensic eye for the details that create an emotional response in the reader. While some characters are extremely unlikeable she still finds small moments that create empathy and connections for the reader. This is a slow burner of a story and doesn’t have any dramatic revelations but carries you along silently as a spectator to the unfolding events; allowing some characters to recreate themselves while others decline and lose authority and respectability....more

review: 4 1/2 stars. While the opening scene is sad it is only as the 10 minutes and 38 seconds tick by,with each subsequent chapter, that your attachment to 4 1/2 stars. While the opening scene is sad it is only as the 10 minutes and 38 seconds tick by,with each subsequent chapter, that your attachment to these characters develop and your anxiety mounts to the true tragedy. I didn’t want to get to the end because I really cared about these people. They are people on the fringe, they are compromised yet they are the type of people that you would want by your side. It’s a kind of reversal in plot because we’ve started at the end and we know the tragedy has already happened so this story is more about how these people have found themselves cast out. The world is a messy place of politically defined borders and religions and the current crisis in Turkey is a distressing example of the need for stories like this. This was a very worthwhile read which still managed to have some uplifting moments. Note: This reminded me a little of The Ministry of Utmost Happiness by Arundati Roy in the way it examines class structures, persecution and geographic borders using many different perspectives....more

review: My interest in Marina Abramovic was sparked after reading ‘The Museum of Modern Love’ by Heather Rose. I had not previously experienced, or thought muMy interest in Marina Abramovic was sparked after reading ‘The Museum of Modern Love’ by Heather Rose. I had not previously experienced, or thought much about, performance art but became curious about why people would be prepared to perform in a way that may harm themselves or produce a transient piece of work. ‘Walk Through Walls’ has answered many of my questions. Marina is a highly sensitive person who has created a legacy through her hard work and dedication to her art. She says performance art is “An art made of trust, vulnerability, and connection.” This is exactly how she reveals herself to the reader and it is an inspirational message. She takes nothing for granted and shows us it is possible to still the body and the mind, and still be present and connected with her audience....more

review: **spoiler alert** 3.5 stars. This story had an intriguing premise ‘why did Evelyn Hugo choose Monique to write her memoir?’ Seemingly she is plucked f**spoiler alert** 3.5 stars. This story had an intriguing premise ‘why did Evelyn Hugo choose Monique to write her memoir?’ Seemingly she is plucked from obscurity but the reader is clearly made aware that the reason will be revealed. Unfortunately, while the reason was well crafted, by the time I got to the reveal I had not built a relationship with Monique and therefore did not feel a great deal of empathy. The story is all Hugo and really the snippets of Monique don’t build her story.Hugo is also a narcissistic, manipulative character and while I understand that she was compelled to make difficult and unpleasant personal choices to hide her sexuality I didn’t like the way she manipulated other people. She was driven by the desire for money, fame and the glamour lifestyle. I didn’t feel sympathy when her life repeatedly disintegrated - in fact I cared less each time. review: This was an intriguing book from beginning to end. A German man who studies beards (yes male facial hair) discovers his wife is having an affair and dThis was an intriguing book from beginning to end. A German man who studies beards (yes male facial hair) discovers his wife is having an affair and decides to teach her a lesson by traveling to Japan on a sort of pilgrimage following the steps of a 500 years deceased Japanese poet. When he arrived in Tokyo he comes across a young Japanese man intent on committing suicide and decides that this man needs his help and guidance. This becomes a strange relationship as both men really don’t understand each other and converse in limited English. There is a strange humour to their journey as they search for a ‘dignified’ location for a suicide and a poetically inspired landscape for contemplation, the Pine Islands. Modern day Japan does not fit the romantic ideals that either man is searching for. I’m not surprised this book has wildly varied s. It’s definitely a bit ‘out there’ but I think it had a lot to say about human expectations and choosing what we will make important in our lives....more

title: The Wife's Tale: A Personal History
author: Edemariam, Aida*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: 3 1/2 stars. This book contains some beautiful prose and some striking glimpses into the domestic life of Edemariam’s grandmother, Yetemegnu, her life3 1/2 stars. This book contains some beautiful prose and some striking glimpses into the domestic life of Edemariam’s grandmother, Yetemegnu, her life encompassed the 20th century (and all its turbulence) in Ethiopia.My prior knowledge of Ethiopia, its geography, history and people was limited to a vague awareness of coups, civil wars, drought and famine. This book has given me a much greater understanding of alternative perspectives. A country with an abundance of produce, deeply rooted Christian beliefs entwined with myths and the spirit world and a strong sense of family pride.While I could picture the daily vistas and could, to some extent, follow the broad brushstrokes of her history I struggled to understand the unfolding political events and the interactions she had with the religious and political figures with whom she met. The oblique (illusory) descriptions of these events made it hard to follow what was actually happening. The time line was also very general and sometimes I felt like it wasn’t chronological or was backtracking to an earlier event.Yetemegnu developed from a young vulnerable girl into a woman; she fought to provide for and protect her children despite her illiteracy and lack of position in a male dominated society. I felt confused about her relationship with her husband, who was clearly abusive and controlling, but for whom she risked a great deal to seek support and obtain his release from prison. About half way through I nearly gave up. Unfamiliar names, dates and events were a little jumbled in my mind but I persevered and found the second half (where the author’s parents enter the story as adults) a lot easier to follow. I think this book would benefit from a short forward giving some context of Ethiopian history to which I could have grounded this story....more

review: 3 1/2 Stars. Thanks to A&U for my uncorrected proof copy. There are many biographies that delve into the experience of living and finding a new life (3 1/2 Stars. Thanks to A&U for my uncorrected proof copy. There are many biographies that delve into the experience of living and finding a new life (or sense of purpose) by spending time abroad but I do feel that Heaslip has managed to delve a little deeper than just ‘a coming of age/ finding romance story. While she does write about these facets of her life I believe her ability to communicate an understanding of Czech culture and history is what I found most interesting. This autobiography provides a glimpse of Prague and it’s people reintegrating with the ‘Western world’ after many years of enforced separation due to political ideology. While many of us have been led (through our Western education) to believe that there was nothing good to come from Communism Tanya Heaslip was confronted with a different reality. Many people were accepting and even happy with their life under communist rule and actually found the transition to democracy a frightening prospect, or at least one that might degrade their strong sense of family and community.I’ve recently read PRAGUE SPRING By Simon Mawer (a fantastic novel set during the 1968 uprising) and I found this useful complementary reading for this novel.I’m not sure I needed quite so many references to Kafka....more

title: Dark Emu
author: Pascoe, Bruce
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is a valuable contribution in encouraging the conversation about how Australia can move forward in an environmentally and politically sustainableThis is a valuable contribution in encouraging the conversation about how Australia can move forward in an environmentally and politically sustainable way while respecting and acknowledging the skills of our first people. Pascoe repeats that we need to move on from past disagreements and labeling of whether Aboriginal people fit the Western view of civilisation because all of our livelihoods now depend on forging a way ahead together. “No peoples of the world in any era of their history wanted oppression, discomfort or inconsequence. The desire for food, shelter and purpose are universal; therefore, systems that provided citizens with as much of those three physical and psychological necessities must be considered successful and, furthermore, the survival of such systems over time can only have been wrought by the will of the people.”Clearly we can not return to the past but Pascoe has presented many examples of land management that could provide benefits to our stressed and degraded landscapes. It’s about thinking in a new way. On occasions Pascoe becomes emotive in his writing but he is able to present a great deal of primary evidence, that has been previously disregarded or overlooked, to support his analysis. Even in his valid condemnation of the attitude and behaviour of some early explorers he has managed to salvage some beneficial evidence from their own first hand accounts. This is definitely a book that should be compulsory reading for Australians and I’m pleased he has written a children’s version as this viewpoint was never included in my formal education....more

title: The Yellow Summer
author: Prou, Suzanne
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I picked this book up at the Lifeline Book Fair. It’s a slim hardback with a plain sunny yellow cover and this edition was printed in 1972. There was I picked this book up at the Lifeline Book Fair. It’s a slim hardback with a plain sunny yellow cover and this edition was printed in 1972. There was no blurb or image of the author and no  on Goodreads. Intrigued I read the first couple of pages and decided it sounded worth pursuing.It’s a quick read but digs deep under your skin looking for what makes people tick. “... and if we still tried, indolently, to discover one fleeting, futile fact, it was that we had come to enjoy ourselves in the warm stagnant pool of our suspicions, our disappointments, our old angers.”This story is set over an August summer on the beach in France where a group of friends meet each year to while away the heat and boredom. It appears that inactivity of the body can lead to overactivity of the mind.When I finished reading this book I did a search on Suzanne Prou and came up with this quote from a New York Times article that really sums up her writing.‘...William Cole wrote in the Saturday Review, "Madame Prou weaves an incredibly fine net, the strands of which are passion, deceit, sadism, pride, seduction and burning hate." And the New Yorker said that she made "the charged atmosphere of decaying provincial life as fascinating as a drop of pond water viewed through the lens of a microscope."’Her book reminded me a little of “Eileen” by Ottessa Moshfegh and the writing of Elizabeth Harrower....more

title: The Cut Out Girl: A Story of War and Family, Lost and Found
author: van Es, Bart
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: 3 1/2 stars. A heartfelt biography that alternates between the time of Nazi occupied Holland and the present day. It is portrayed through the eyes of 3 1/2 stars. A heartfelt biography that alternates between the time of Nazi occupied Holland and the present day. It is portrayed through the eyes of Lientje, a young Jewish girl, who was (mostly) hidden in plain sight during the occupation when she was sent to live with a non Jewish family. The author has a direct connection to Lientje and spent a lot of time interviewing her during the writing and research of this book and he also includes chapters about these conversations to provide clarity. He has compassionately tried to reconstruct her story through the lens of a naive child. There are blanks in this story due to memory loss, which is no doubt due to post traumatic stress, and although van Es doesn’t use the term ‘survivor guilt’ this is the expression I would use to describe the impact the occupation had on her life. While some Dutch people did shelter Jewish citizens it appears it was sometimes out of a sense of religious or philosophical duty rather than the true bond of family love and protection. Being removed from culture, family and everything familiar must have been a huge trauma to bear. ...more

title: Paris Echo
author: Faulks, Sebastian
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: While I really liked the historical elements in this novel and the sense of time slip created while wandering the Parisian backstreets the main characWhile I really liked the historical elements in this novel and the sense of time slip created while wandering the Parisian backstreets the main characters of Hannah and Tariq were a miss for me. I didn’t need to like them but I did need to be interested in them - I wasn’t. They became slightly more fleshed out by the end of the novel but I needed them earlier as they were the deliverers of the backstories of the women of Paris during the occupation. The relationship between Hannah and Tariq was also not one I could believe. The stories of the young women of Paris were fascinating. What to do when you are caught in the middle of the war as a civilian? What are the rules? Faulks delved into these questions skilfully and provided conflicting scenarios.The subway provided a great grounding connection for the time shift between the past and present. It also invoked an element of magical realism with a supporting cast of Victor Hugo and a couple of women (that Tariq followed and who could not really be placed in time). Maybe Faulks tried to do too much and therefore left too much unresolved. Tariq’s mother?, the money drop?, the Chinese immigrants?, the Algerian story? ......more

review: 4 1/2 stars on reread. This book is so excruciating to read. How can two young people who clearly love and understand each other so intrinsically be s4 1/2 stars on reread. This book is so excruciating to read. How can two young people who clearly love and understand each other so intrinsically be so lacking in belief or trust about the reality of their relationship. The apparent simplicity of the writing baffles me as the story is deeply nuanced and the relationship complex. This is not as edgy as Conversations With Friends but I enjoyed it so much more because I was emotionally invested with both the protagonists. I felt Rooney captured the self doubt and behaviour of young adults with clarity and compassion. Their ‘tumultuous’ lives are contrasted cleverly by scenes of simple domesticity and It’s all so ‘normal’. The sadness associated with their miscommunication and timing reminded me of the feeling I got reading Atonement and On Chesil Beach. This is the most straightforward of this year’s ManBooker novels in terms of language and sentence structure (that I’ve read so far) but it is a beautifully crafted relatable story that I’m sure will gain a large audience....more

review: 4 1/2 starsThis is a uniquely constructed and disturbing novel about paranoia and fear where “the vulnerable reciprocity of giving and receiving “ is 4 1/2 starsThis is a uniquely constructed and disturbing novel about paranoia and fear where “the vulnerable reciprocity of giving and receiving “ is to be avoided at all costs. I’m not surprised it has been short listed for The ManBooker prize, it has a big story to tell. It’s set in Northern Ireland during the 1970’s but it could be many civil wars. This novel shows what happens when individual power disguises itself as part of a societal cause. This has 1984 undertones but also could be a precursor to how we might arrive at a patriarchal society like that which occurs in The Handmaids Tale. There is dark humour in the ridiculousness and warped sense of patriotism and righteousness that results in ‘normal ‘ murder appearing shocking and appalling and where ‘reading while walking’ is subversive.I felt like I was wading in knee deep water while reading this book. It requires slow close attention. It’s dense and sometimes repetitive as it dissects each comment and thought to it’s true meaning but the reward is worth the effort....more

author: Doherty, Ben
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: 4 1/2 stars. What a wonderful surprise. Despite being a novel Ben Doherty provides a powerful and adroitly written insight into a minority population.4 1/2 stars. What a wonderful surprise. Despite being a novel Ben Doherty provides a powerful and adroitly written insight into a minority population. The Naga people face hardship in the form of discrimination, poverty and embedded diseases such as HIV yet they are also proud of their heritage and are extremely loyal. This novel skilfully balances fact with fable to create a story that is about love and survival. In a world where we increasingly receive news from social media I think this story also exemplifies the need for embedded journalists. Doherty’s time in South Asia and his understanding of the background events that underlie the rifts and dislocation of minority groups has allowed him to craft a story that celebrates the value of human diversity and the need to preserve and value it....more

The first person narrator, Herra, is at first a very obnoxious and unlikeable cranky old woman but as her history is revealed it becomes more and more apparent that this is a woman who has suffered enormously. She is still sharp and obnoxious but also funny and highly observant. There are definitely laugh out loud moments amongst the carnage.The Icelandic sense of place is also very much in the foreground as the narrator describes the relationship of her people with the people of other countries in Europe. review: Joan Healy wrote this book with purpose. She wanted to convey the terribleness of the situation in Cambodia but also preserve and recognise the dignitJoan Healy wrote this book with purpose. She wanted to convey the terribleness of the situation in Cambodia but also preserve and recognise the dignity of its people. title: The Plains
author: Murnane, Gerald
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I won’t presume an affectation (a new word I learned while reading this book!) that I really understood this novel. It is dense, contains long meanderI won’t presume an affectation (a new word I learned while reading this book!) that I really understood this novel. It is dense, contains long meandering sentences and makes allusions to things (and I was not always sure what those things were). Occasionally I glimpsed, or guessed- and who knows if I was right, what Murnane was trying to say.I’ve given this three stars based on the thinking that it is probably my own lack of understanding that was the problem rather than the writing, which did include some intriguing descriptions and thoughts. Unfortunately I struggled to access this book and probably spent more time trying to analyse the content than just rolling with it. There is little action and the characters are a group of fictional people (called the plainsmen) who are mysterious and difficult to know. This in turn makes it a struggle to find any emotional connection to this novel.In this time where experimental fiction seems to be winning lots of prizes I’m not surprised that one of Murnane’s book (not this one) has been nominated for the Miles Franklin literary award....more

review: I particularly enjoyed this book as I grew up in Western Australia and have holidayed on the beach between Perth and Geraldton on numerous occasions. I particularly enjoyed this book as I grew up in Western Australia and have holidayed on the beach between Perth and Geraldton on numerous occasions. Sam Carmody has captured the sights, sounds and smells so accurately. I also vividly remember visiting a crayfish processing factory in Geraldton on my year 7 school camp and it was this image that I saw each time Arcadia (the fishing boat) went to sea. I remember the brutality of the crayfish being beheaded. A brutality also perpetrated by the behaviour of many of the characters in this book.Paul is a young man moving into adulthood with the growing realisation that he cannot maintain control of everything in his world. review: Despite this being a fairly horrific tale of survival on a remote Stac in Scotland it is (mostly) a wonderful story of humanity. The naivety of the chDespite this being a fairly horrific tale of survival on a remote Stac in Scotland it is (mostly) a wonderful story of humanity. The naivety of the characters provides a gentle humour that makes them endearing and ultimately makes the story uplifting.I was interested to read that this is based on a true story as it reminded me of a similar incident in New Zealand where a group of fur sealers were left, for nearly four years, (Open Bay Islands, 1810) when their ship failed to return at the end of the season to collect them. It sunk shortly after leaving them. As I gazed out off the south west coast of NZ at these islands I could only imagine how terrifying it must have been. This might be a book best read in summer as it is extremely chilly and makes Australian winters look blissful....more

title: Border Districts: A Fiction
author: Murnane, Gerald
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Once again Murnane throws me into a bit of a spin. I think the difficulty with his writing is that as a work of fiction I’m comparing it to other noveOnce again Murnane throws me into a bit of a spin. I think the difficulty with his writing is that as a work of fiction I’m comparing it to other novels. On reflection I think it would be better to describe it as a fictional essay. If doesn’t really have a plot so you don’t feel like you are going anywhere, rather it is an intense examination and reflection of the protagonist’s (or author’s?) metacognition. With great skill Murnane is able to describe his thinking and then share these moments that are very much like synapses in the human brain. They are the moments where you leap in another direction. His fascination with coloured glass in all its forms, and how it appears differently depending on which side you look at it from or who is looking at it, is a thoughtful analogy to explain how our world view and memories are shaped. This is an interesting read but not an easy book to digest. I’m glad I made the effort. ...more

review: Thanks to Allen&Unwin for my copy of The Yellow House. This is a desperate and tragic story about the impact of inherited guilt. The pressure, both inThanks to Allen&Unwin for my copy of The Yellow House. This is a desperate and tragic story about the impact of inherited guilt. The pressure, both internal and external on this family is immense and builds steadily in this pressure cooker of a town. Cub’s mother is severely depressed and almost catatonic, her father is struggling to hold the family together and her elder brother Cassie responds as you would expect from a disenfranchised teenager.What I loved about this novel was the narration by Cub, the young daughter. She is a realistic narrator, she is inquisitive but naive, she watches what happens but doesn’t tell us what it means, she doesn’t ‘just’ put the pieces together. She’s simply a young girl who loves her family and doesn’t want to see any of them hurting. This was skilfully done!At about the 3/4 point of this novel I was racing through the pages as revelations were made and expectations of a big event became clear but I think that it went off the boil a little before the climax. Perhaps it needed something else here. While Cub shone her twin brother, Wally, faded as a character and I think he could of revealed a bit more here of his experience. He was the only one likely to talk and share his knowledge with Cub.Definitely a book I would recommend for originality and authenticity. A great first novel....more

title: The Town
author: Prescott, Shaun
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I was feeling like I might be the victim of some sort of fraudulent activity. Am I really reading a book about nothing? If the protagonist is trying tI was feeling like I might be the victim of some sort of fraudulent activity. Am I really reading a book about nothing? If the protagonist is trying to write a history of a town (unnamed - central west New South Wales) that no one knows the history of and there are no known written records - does it really have a history?The dead-pan pathos and humour of this narrative when combined with the increasingly bizarre speculative fiction had me hooked. While nothing happens in this town (apart from excessive drinking and quite a bit of brawling) I really wanted to find out where the labyrinth was going to end. A bus driver who drives an endless looping of town without passengers, a radio station with no listeners and a pub with no customers (but yes everyone drinks) and don’t get me started on all those cassette tapes. I guess I know where blank cassettes ended up when people stopped buying them.This is definitely a slightly bonkers read but it also does make some powerful points about how generic our country towns have become with the growth of large chain stores and how many have (and continue) to disappear into obscurity. They only really exist for the people that live in them and those people can fear what they don’t know. I also think there was quite a bit to be said about how we worry about all the small issues and around us the world is facing much bigger issues that will effect the entire planet. It might actually be that we are all actually disappearing into a big hole of nothing.The final 1/3 of the book was not quite as gripping. The humour was no longer there and the grim reality of the underbelly of most of our big cities was probably a lot more familiar.Bran Presser has raved about how underrated (or perhaps under the radar ) this book has been and I definitely agree it is pretty special. The writing style reminds me a bit of The Cage by Lloyd Jones....more

title: Sight
author: Greengrass, Jessie
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I think I read most of this book on the verge of tears and I’m not feeling much better now. The atmosphere and language are exquisite.This is an extraI think I read most of this book on the verge of tears and I’m not feeling much better now. The atmosphere and language are exquisite.This is an extraordinary portrayal of a woman trying to make sense of her role as a daughter and granddaughter to two women (both deceased). It is full of regret for the inadequacy of her understanding of them and the questions she didn’t ask. It is now her own time to weigh up the option of whether to become a mother and this decision is accompanied by a fear of being inadequate and the certainty that this child must be nurtured and raised to be their own person.“Our lives are possibility reduced to rough particularity by contact, touch, and out of it the specificity of each of us come, so that to ask if we might have been better otherwise is to wish ourselves undone”Interspersed within our narrators personal reflection she reveals three fascinating scientific stories of humans attempting to see and understand the human body. Rontgen’s X-ray of human bones, Freud’s psychoanalysis attempts ‘sight’ of the mind and John Hunter’s use of anatomical surgery to map a pregnant body. There is a belief that with sight will come understanding.I’m feeling very inadequate with this  as there is so much more to think about. It would be a worthy winner for the Women’s Prize which it is currently shortlisted for. ...more

title: The Trial
author: Kafka, Franz
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: On the plus side:For its time (1914) this novel must have been extremely experimental in its plotting because even now it feels unusual and exploratorOn the plus side:For its time (1914) this novel must have been extremely experimental in its plotting because even now it feels unusual and exploratory in the way crucial information is withheld from both the characters and the readers for the entire novel. Also, one of the main issues that the novel tackles, of placing the importance of process over progress is still highly relevant for many people who work in large organisations, both private and government.On the negative: I guess it is more the language and the lack of emotional variation in the novel that didn’t win me over. The main character Joseph K. appears to be confused, frustrated and somewhat angry throughout the novel, without any period of happiness or improved prospect. I like some ups and downs rather than a continual downward spiral because I need hope or prospects even if it isn’t going to happen!I feel like I see definite glimpses of how this style of writing has played out in more contemporary novels such as ‘My Year of Rest and Relaxation ‘ by Ottessa Moshfegh and ‘The Cage’ by Lloyd Jones. It is clearly an important influence and worth appreciating for this.My one question would be what the significance was of the female characters in the book? I found them very odd. I understand Kafka had issues with female relationships but I don’t understand their presence in the book....more

title: The Cage
author: Jones, Lloyd
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is definitely a grim allegorical tale which examines, with unpleasant intensity, our moral compasses and a tendency for our politicians (and manyThis is definitely a grim allegorical tale which examines, with unpleasant intensity, our moral compasses and a tendency for our politicians (and many others) to demonstrate a lack of social and emotional intelligence. The juxtaposition of the naive narrator and the extreme calculated ill treatment of the ‘strangers’ by the ‘Trustees’ caused me to cringe with distaste.I felt like Lloyd Jones was placing one of those mirrors from a ‘hall of mirrors’ maze in front of the reader. We think we know what we look like but the reflection is disturbing and unattractive and you want to deny what you see.This is a very clever book examining the plight of refugees and the use of incarceration and what it may or may not hope to achieve. There is a strong stink of ‘shit’ that pervades every corner of this book (literally and figuratively) and a lady who wears a hat that is desperately being waited for - she is hope.This book provides a different perspective to Exit West but is similar in its use of magical realism as a tool to grapple with a difficult conversation....more

review: DNF ( I read about half). I really wanted to like this book and for the first quarter I did. The anecdotes, conversational style and different narratoDNF ( I read about half). I really wanted to like this book and for the first quarter I did. The anecdotes, conversational style and different narrators complemented the rugged, gregarious, passionate character I was beginning to admire. Unfortunately the book lost me from this point. It began to get very repetitive and bogged down in all of the issues that surround the indigenous movement. I wanted the stories about Tracker (the biography) not a blow by blow account of every event that occurred during the 80’s and 90’s that involved indigenous people. I accept that Tracker wars front and centre to many of these issues but many of the narrators did not have anything new to contribute to the story. It just felt like they were included to lend more weight to the number of people who admired or were influenced by him.I’m pleased I read what I did because I think he was an admirable individual with a great love for life and his country....more

review: This book is not an easy read. Religious persecution is not a nice topic and this novel ventures into territory that is traumatic and at times the allThis book is not an easy read. Religious persecution is not a nice topic and this novel ventures into territory that is traumatic and at times the allegorical writing is difficult to follow.However, it made me think and wonder about what happens to individuals, family and community when all hope is lost. How people can either choose to live and accept evil, lose connections with their past or just live in the moment in order to survive.There are a number of references to the Zoroastrians who were a religious society that inhabited parts of Iran prior to the arrival of Islam. Their beliefs include the use of fire and water as agents of ritual purity. This helped me to understand some of the flood/fire/water events in this book. There are also numerous references to Persian folk stories and characters that help create the surreal world presented in this novel....more

title: The Opal Dragonfly
author: Leatherdale, Julian*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Thanks to Goodreads and Allen & Unwin for my copy of this novel. I have mixed feelings about this book so I’ve ended up middle of the road with my finThanks to Goodreads and Allen & Unwin for my copy of this novel. I have mixed feelings about this book so I’ve ended up middle of the road with my final rating. I think the setting and time were captured well and the cast of characters were broad and generally engaging. The descriptions of daily life, the public events, political disagreements and social society of Sydney were fascinating and enjoyable to read about.My two major difficulties were the character of the young Isobel and the handling of the indigenous issues. I didn’t find the depth of Isobel’s perceptions and moralising as a young child realistic. I just can’t imagine a young child with limited exposure of the world thinking about things so deeply. From about half way through the novel I was much more convinced by her behaviour and the growth of her character but I struggled through her early years. The handling of indigenous issues is tricky and I am not sure how successful many writers are at not viewing these issues through a lens of modern opinion and sensibility. I appreciate that Leatherdale was trying to overcome this by providing two opposing stories of the Major’s expeditions but then this also feels a bit contrived. It’s like our heroine could not be a strong and righteous character if she didn’t come out and condemn her father’s actions because of what we now know about the treatment of indigenous people. Overall I would recommend this if you like a neatly tied up Australian historical novel and it would be a good book club choice....more

review: This book is a story of love that is full of melancholy and beauty. Yes it is really sad. I don’t know much about T.S. Eliot’s writing but about half This book is a story of love that is full of melancholy and beauty. Yes it is really sad. I don’t know much about T.S. Eliot’s writing but about half way through the book I googled some background on him and listened to his poem ‘The Love Song of Alfred Prufrock’ https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PLNsP... It was a revelation as I heard Anthony Hopkins read lines like “Time yet for a hundred indecisions...” - I saw the cleverness of a poem embedded in a novel. Emily is a procrastinator and paralysed by indecision which ultimately leads to her predicament in the novel. Steven Carroll is obviously passionate about T.S. Eliot and has captured a little of the essence of him in his own writing. However you certainly don’t need to be familiar with Eliot to appreciate this book. I have never read a book by Steven Carroll before but will certainly be revisiting him.This novel also reminded me a little of Mothering Sunday by Graham Swift as it captures a moment reflected upon and a love that is destined to be unfulfilled.It is much gentler but with a similar feel....more

title: The Transit of Venus
author: Hazzard, Shirley
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: What a stellar read. This book just keeps giving and giving and wow the final plot twist was a cracker. It did take me awhile to adjust to the writingWhat a stellar read. This book just keeps giving and giving and wow the final plot twist was a cracker. It did take me awhile to adjust to the writing style and language but I became totally hooked. The characters are intense and multilayered and the descriptions are sharp and humorous:“Tertia’s mother said, “She spoils every dinner party she attends.” Fond and proud. Crushing a billowing blue sofa, Lady Drage now became a creature too heavy for its elements, a cormorant on the waves.”The three sisters, Dora, Caro and Grace, arrive in London together, shortly after the Second World War. The timing of their arrival, and the 30 subsequent years the novel covers, sees the struggle against patriarchy, class division and the establishment begin to crumble but yet still impact their lives and relationships. Each sister makes decisions that see their future paths and happiness diverge.The men in this book are also fascinating- and not generally in a good way. How I loathed Christian and his abhorrent mealy mouthed comments. I can’t even begin to elaborate on Paul but you really need to get to the end of the book to know him!The changing times are captured exquisitely by Hazzard using precise pared back descriptions of locations making you feel you are always in the moment....more

review: This novel is difficult to rate because the content is at times traumatic and generally unpleasant but the writing and message are extremely powerful.This novel is difficult to rate because the content is at times traumatic and generally unpleasant but the writing and message are extremely powerful. The distillation of what it means to be alive and in love is captured by the detailed descriptions of Dinesh as he examines the events that have led to his current situation as a newly married man and a refugee in war zone. While I would generally not appreciate reading about someone’s bowel movements, and other personal hygiene moments, I understand that the author is delving into how humans respond when they have lost all sense of hope. This is definitely a valuable read for anyone trying to understand the impact of civil war and/or the displacement of minority people....more

review: Obviously giving this a 4 star rating means that overall I thought it was a very good book but I was extremely glad to get to the end of it. The conceObviously giving this a 4 star rating means that overall I thought it was a very good book but I was extremely glad to get to the end of it. The concept of 4 diverging lives for one person was a fascinating idea and setting this in the mid twentieth century allowed the author to share many amazing moments in history. Each Archie was a fascinating person and a truely developed character in his own right. Unfortunately I do feel that Auster really tried to cram to much into this story and that tipped me a little over the edge. The endless lists of books read, movies visited and unrelated events felt like an attempt to show how well read etc Auster is. Clearly, he is well read but I don’t think I needed a blow by blow recitation. I guess domestic American history is also not my favourite thing as I don’t have any connection or ownership to it. This is clearly a brilliantly conceived novel but I would be hesitant in recommending it without warning....more

review: This was an intriguing book. While it began as an account of Jordi Magraner, a Spaniard, who became obsessed with searching for the Baramanu (Yeti) inThis was an intriguing book. While it began as an account of Jordi Magraner, a Spaniard, who became obsessed with searching for the Baramanu (Yeti) in the Hindu Kush (Pakistan border near Afghanistan) it shifted to an exploration of the local Kalash people and the impact of the Taliban in this region. While Jordi's lifestyle was somewhat complicated, his motives not always clear and his mental state obsessive he obviously cared deeply for this minority group; that remains largely unknown, destitute and persecuted. Parts of this book were a bit slow and repetitive and I think a detailed map of the region would have been invaluable in understanding the geography of this region. review: Thanks to A&U and Goodreads for my copy of Wonderful Feels Like This. I have mixed feelings about this book. The premise of the story is an interestinThanks to A&U and Goodreads for my copy of Wonderful Feels Like This. I have mixed feelings about this book. The premise of the story is an interesting choice if this is intended as a YA novel. The parts narrated by Steffi, a year 9 secondary student, who is bullied and has feelings of not quite fitting in are typical of this genre but the voice of Alvar, a nursing home patient whom Steffi befriends, really felt a bit odd for a YA novel. As an adult I really liked Alvar's story of his adolescence in Stockholm during WW11 but I didn't feel much connection with Steffi's character ( even though I could empathise with her predicament). I'm not particularly musical so a bit of the detail about the playing of jazz probably also went over my head. I also felt the translation was at times a bit stilted and I wonder how the lines of lyrics were translated (if they were). I must say I loved the ending and thought it tied the novel together beautifully while dealing with some important issues....more

review: This was a very powerful and moving novel about relationships. The allegory of seasons is used to represent the different stages of grief. There is also a great deal of symbolism within the novel such as fire, birth, death and the fox. The more I think about this story the more complex and layered it becomes. The only thing I would have liked would be a bit more context to explain the origins of this 'Old Germanic' group of people. author: King, Ross

review: I thoroughly enjoyed this book. It was so much more than just about Monet. I guess if that's all you wanted to read about it may have been tedious butI thoroughly enjoyed this book. It was so much more than just about Monet. I guess if that's all you wanted to read about it may have been tedious but I enjoyed the grand sweep of 20th century history and felt the author retold the nuances and events of this time in an interesting and informative way. Occasionally there was a bit much repetition about personalities and events but overall it flowed smoothly. It did take a long time to read this book and was a significant investment in my reading time (I did however only tackle it in small portions) but I certainly learnt a great deal about war, politics and art at the turn of the twentieth century. Thanks to Bloomsbury Circus for my copy which I won on Twitter....more

review: Thanks to Allen and Unwin and Goodreads for my copy of Fearless.This book explored numerous themes through a cast of characters. They were interestingThanks to Allen and Unwin and Goodreads for my copy of Fearless.This book explored numerous themes through a cast of characters. They were interesting and diverse but this also made them detrimental to the pace of the plot. It took a long time to develop backstories for all the characters which therefore meant that the action really didn't begin to take place until over halfway through the novel. While individually all of the characters were interesting I felt the net result was that the plot suffered by being a bit obvious and streamlined and the ending was a little too neat. The author did raise some good issues about race, religion, poverty and 'third world' (developing country) tourism so overall I found this book a worthwhile read....more

Beatty, like his protagonist Bonbon, has used subterfuge, in the form of a novel, to discuss an unpalatable topic. If Beatty had tried to deal with racism in a non-fiction format I think his audience, like Bonbon's, would be restricted to 'Dickens' and the already converted (or perhaps just aware) citizens of our planet. Winning the Man Booker prize must surely be the icing on the cake. Humour has been used cleverly and with great skill in this novel. The only draw back for me was my limited experience of the full spectrum of US urban culture and colloquialisms....more

I didn't think about changing my life. My life had already been changed. I just had to get through it." Patchett has skilfully examined how fate and regret can alter and consume lives and ripple through those around us. review: I don’t usually read other people’s s before I write my own but today I did and I’m a little disappointed. I was thinking I would write that thiI don’t usually read other people’s s before I write my own but today I did and I’m a little disappointed. I was thinking I would write that this reminded me of a Shakespeare tragedy but now I’ve discovered this is common knowledge so I’m late to the party! McEwan obviously had a bit of fun with this novel (novella) as the use of a talking foetus provides excellent opportunity for soliloquies. I think what saves this book from being just black, rather than black comedy, is the highfalutin language of the foetus along with it’s absurd knowledge of wine and food. There were still a number of moments where I felt uncomfortable with scenes in the book, and for which I could not find humour, but I was propelled to the end with the expectation of delightful revenge....more

Thanks to Scribe and Goodreads for my copy of A Beautiful Young Wife. Although this novel (novella?) appears to be a simple recount it tackles a number of relationship themes; ageing, children, trust and the effect of time. Edward, the protagonist, finds himself spiralling out of control and making choices that in turn lead to further repercussions. He does not seem to be able to alter his trajectory but his awareness does grow as he reflects on his childhood and past. This story certainly provokes and Wieringa does a good job of not overpowering the readers responses with his own commentary or opinion. The translation was easy to read and well structured. Overall an interesting read....more

review: This is a complex and fascinating read that weaves together Camorra, Cosa Nostra, Mafia and the politics of post war Italy. At times I felt overwhelmeThis is a complex and fascinating read that weaves together Camorra, Cosa Nostra, Mafia and the politics of post war Italy. At times I felt overwhelmed by the complexity of the topic but as I continued to read I found the threads coming together to create a complete picture of this period in history. I really enjoyed the travelogue components that included history, culture and the food of Naples and Sicily, along with the interviews and descriptions with some significant spectators to the unfolding events. After recently reading the Neapolitan series by Ferrante I now feel I have a much better understanding of the scene in Naples, and perhaps also her reasoning for remaining anonymous and writing a fictional account. These were clearly times when it was dangerous to be identified and speak your mind....more

At some points the book is a bit emotive (and I don't blame her) but this may make her argument appear biased. I believe a lot of educators would agree with her sentiments but also, like students, feel trapped within our current system. review: Thanks to A&U and Goodreads for this proof copy.I thoroughly enjoyed this book. It provided a fascinating and tactile history of Tasmania (Van Dieman'Thanks to A&U and Goodreads for this proof copy.I thoroughly enjoyed this book. It provided a fascinating and tactile history of Tasmania (Van Dieman's Land) brought to life by vivid description of landscape and carefully drawn character portraits. If I could wish for one thing it would be the addition of a character list/map as there were so many important people connected in numerous ways and I found it difficult to keep track of who some of them were. This was apparent from the first few pages, which I found a bit overwhelming with detail. I really wanted to understand and keep track of all the players, it was like an intricate spiders web being woven. This book would make a fantastic mini-series and is a wonderful way to recount history. It definitely doesn't need to ride on the 'coat tails' of Jane Eyre as it is worthy on its own merits....more

review: Thanks to Goodreads and Hachette Australia for my proof copy. Wow! what an amazing book. I'm finding it difficult to let it go as I've been completelyThanks to Goodreads and Hachette Australia for my proof copy. Wow! what an amazing book. I'm finding it difficult to let it go as I've been completely invested for the past week. Erdrich has constructed a beautiful tale around complex, multifaceted characters who feel completely believable. I felt anger, sorrow, resentment and empathy about the way these characters, particularly the children, were dealt with and the confrontations and personal upheavals they endured. I enjoyed the magical realism that was deftly woven through the different time periods in this book and how it made me feel like I was floating above the narrative during the time shifts. This book was also interesting because of the insight into indigenous America and its relevance and continuance within its contemporary culture....more
