title: These Tumultuous Years
author: Podbury, Dudley James
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Thank you for my Goodreads copy of this book.These Tumultuous Years is a strongly plot driven book. I enjoyed the journey through a variety of countriThank you for my Goodreads copy of this book.These Tumultuous Years is a strongly plot driven book. I enjoyed the journey through a variety of countries and continents. The historical feel of the settings was complemented by the writing style. I particularly felt the 'war scenes' were the most convincingly written part of the book.However I did struggle with the characters in the book. They seemed to be either evil and abhorrent or generous and kind to a fault. It is not until we meet Gunther that I felt we had embraced a character who seemed realistic and had some depth. Many of the descriptions were quite stereotyped and therefore did not leave much to the imagination. The other issue I struggled with in this book was how the author finished many chapters or scenes with a sentence or paragraph that eluded to what would happen next in the story. I felt this was unnecessary and actually detracted from the suspense of the story. I wanted to discover these things on my own. Overall this book has some merit but could be much better with stronger editing....more

The river was a sensory and nostalgic experience, a snap shot of Australian life. I also really enjoyed the 'river men' and the special way Birch developed their place in the story of the river and the lives of Ren and Sonny....more

title: The First Stone: Some Questions about Sex and Power
author: Garner, Helen
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I’ve just read the 25th anniversary edition of this book, which included extra epilogue material post the original release, that added another layer tI’ve just read the 25th anniversary edition of this book, which included extra epilogue material post the original release, that added another layer to this story. While the lack of work place equality, abuse of power in workplace relationships and unwanted sexual advances continue to be a problem the conversation needs to be open, respectful and continue to explore how we (people) can all take responsibility and work towards improving this imbalance. While I don’t agree with all of Garner’s arguments I certainly don’t feel she should have been demonised in the way she was when this book was first released. Yes she inserted her own opinions and personal reflections into her examination of the events but I also believe she made this entirely clear. I don’t see how she was ever going to use this as a ‘money grabbing’ exercise off the back of someone else’s pain as not many books in Australia really make that kind of money. She genuinely cares about the topic, and I can’t imagine anyone would put themselves through the abuse and resistance she received otherwise. How we educate our children and our own behaviour are all within our power and Garner has used her power to write and exam issues in a way that is both readable and engaging. If a lot of men have read this book (and this is mentioned in the epilogue) I don’t necessarily see this as a problem indicating support but rather an opportunity to make them stop and think about their behaviour.I was at university around the time the events in this book were written and it was a completely different experience. It was modern, without colleges and none of the history of traditional formalities and behaviours that are perpetuated in the institutions of this book. At the time I felt I may have been missing out but now I can reflect that maybe I was the lucky one....more

review: This is certainly an issue worthy of writing about but I guess I'm just thinking that Australia is a long way ahead of the USA in terms of recognisingThis is certainly an issue worthy of writing about but I guess I'm just thinking that Australia is a long way ahead of the USA in terms of recognising and dealing with these sorts of issues, and therefore the story did not engage me as much as I would have liked. Nutt writes well when she focuses on the legal issues involved but I did not feel her scientific knowledge was convincingly written. It felt like she was just recounting someone else's opinion without really understanding it. The book was also quite repetitive which caused me to skim some parts. Nutt had obviously taken great care to accurately portray the family in a sensitive and accurate manner and in this respect she has provided a positive service for transgender people and their families....more

review: I enjoyed the premise and setting of this book but it fell short in the end. I felt that the childhood chapters were engaging to begin with but meandeI enjoyed the premise and setting of this book but it fell short in the end. I felt that the childhood chapters were engaging to begin with but meandered without direction after a couple of major incidents in Jayne's life. The contemporary chapters, following Jayne's life, also started with great promise and I was looking forward to a journey delving into Aboriginal artefacts, their removal and return however this didn't really evolve either. There seemed to be a greater focus on what Jayne was eating and her cycling than on her research and passion for Australian history. I got excited when she discovered some artefacts in a box and I wanted to know more about these and their backstory. Perhaps there were just too many unrelated ideas going on in this novel.The end of the novel was also abrupt with a neatly tied up but slightly unbelievable finish....more

review: This book probes deeply into relationships and the undercurrents that touch all of us; spouses, friends, family and acquaintances. How we perceive andThis book probes deeply into relationships and the undercurrents that touch all of us; spouses, friends, family and acquaintances. How we perceive and judge people and the implications and effects of our behaviour may be unseen but are rarely without consequence to someone. Lorenzo also tackles the role of the media in passing judgement but also on our dependence of it. I found this book provoking, thoughtful and compassionate.
